{{DISPLAYTITLE:{{mp|(177049) 2003 EE|16}}}} {{Infobox planet | minorplanet = yes | background = #FFC2E0 | name = {{mp|(177049) 2003 EE|16}} | discovery_ref = | discoverer = [[Spacewatch]] | discovery_site = [[Kitt Peak National Observatory|Kitt Peak National Obs.]] | discovered = 8 March 2003 | mpc_name = {{mp|(177049) 2003 EE|16}} | mp_category = [[Near-Earth object|NEO]]{{·}}[[Potentially hazardous asteroid|PHA]]{{·}}[[Apollo asteroid|Apollo]]  | orbit_ref = | epoch = 13 January 2016 ([[Julian day|JD]] 2457400.5) | aphelion = {{Convert|2.2878|AU|Gm|abbr=on|lk=on}} | perihelion = {{Convert|0.54666|AU|Gm|abbr=on}} | semimajor = {{Convert|1.4172|AU|Gm|abbr=on}} | eccentricity = 0.61427 | period = 1.69 [[Julian year (astronomy)|yr]] (616.24 [[Julian year (astronomy)|d]]) | inclination = 0.64964° | asc_node = 127.04° | mean_anomaly = 296.40[[Degree (angle)|°]] | arg_peri = 259.67° | mean_diameter = {{val|0.320}} km | mass = 5.1{{e|10}} kg (assumed) | abs_magnitude = 19.7 | mean_motion = {{Deg2DMS|0.58419|sup=ms}} / day | observation_arc = 4429 days (12.13 yr) |earliest_precovery_date = 17 May 2002 | uncertainty = 0 | moid = {{Convert|9.93475E-5|AU|km|abbr=on}} }} '''{{mp|(177049) 2003 EE|16}}''', [[Provisional designation in astronomy|provisionally known]] as '''2003 EE16''', is an [[Apollo asteroid|Apollo]] [[near-Earth asteroid]] and [[potentially hazardous object]]. It was discovered on 8 March 2003 by [[Spacewatch|LPL/Spacewatch II]] at an [[apparent magnitude]] of 20 using a {{convert|1.8|m|in|adj=on|sp=us}} [[reflecting telescope]]. It has an estimated diameter of {{convert|320|m|sp=us}}. The asteroid was listed on [[Sentry (monitoring system)|Sentry Risk Table]] with a [[Torino Scale]] rating of 1 on 2 April 2003. == Description == Many of the virtual impactors were located near the [[Curve fitting|nominal]] orbital solution and the asteroid has a low inclination relative to Earth's orbit. Observation by the [[Very Large Telescope]] (VLT) 8 meter facilities on 22 May and 19 June 2003 when {{mp|2003 EE|16}} was very dim with an apparent magnitude between 24–25At an [[apparent magnitude]] of 24, the asteroid was roughly 10 million times fainter than can be seen with the [[naked eye]].
Math: (\sqrt[5]{100})^{24-6.5}= 10000000 refined the orbit. It was removed from the Sentry Risk Table on 28 May 2003. {{mp|2003 EE|16}} has the smallest Earth [[Minimum orbit intersection distance]] (MOID) of any known [[potentially hazardous asteroid]]. The Earth MOID is {{convert|0.0000475|AU|km mi|abbr=on|lk=on}}. Asteroids with a smaller Earth MOID are less than ~100 meters in diameter such as {{mpl|2013 XY|8}} and {{mpl|2010 TD|54}}. Earth impactors {{mpl|2008 TC|3}} and [[2014 AA]] had small Earth MOID values as they were on their impact approach when discovered. {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:left" |+Close-approaches to Earth |- ! Date !! Distance from Earth |- | 2014-07-01 || {{convert|0.0966|AU|km mi|abbr=on|lk=on}} (37.6 [[Lunar distance (astronomy)|LD]]) |- | 2041-07-01 || {{convert|0.0992|AU|km mi|abbr=on|lk=off}} (38.6 LD) |- | 2067-01-31 || {{convert|0.0874|AU|km mi|abbr=on|lk=off}} (34.0 LD) |- | 2094-01-30 || {{convert|0.0747|AU|km mi|abbr=on|lk=off}} (29.1 LD) |- | 2122-07-04 || {{convert|0.0743|AU|km mi|abbr=on|lk=off}} (28.9 LD) |- | 2149-07-06 || {{convert|0.0518|AU|km mi|abbr=on|lk=off}} (20.2 LD) |- | 2175-02-02 || {{convert|0.0802|AU|km mi|abbr=on|lk=off}} (31.2 LD) |} == Notes == {{Reflist|group="note"}} == {{DISPLAYTITLE:{{mp|2007 VE|191}}}} {{Infobox planet | minorplanet = yes | background = #FFC2E0 | name = {{mp|2007 VE|191}} | discovery_ref = | discoverer = [[Mount Lemmon Survey|Mt. Lemmon Survey]] ([[List of observatory codes#G00–G99|G96]]) | discovered = 15 November 2007 | mpc_name = {{mp|2007 VE|191}} | mp_category = [[Near-Earth object|NEO]]{{·}}[[List of Apollo asteroids|Apollo]] | orbit_ref = | epoch = 13 January 2016 ([[Julian day|JD]] 2457400.5) | observation_arc = 13 days
(last seen 2007) | aphelion = {{Convert|3.1065|AU|Gm|abbr=on|lk=on}} (Q) | perihelion = {{Convert|0.71060|AU|Gm|abbr=on}} (q) | semimajor = {{Convert|1.9085|AU|Gm|abbr=on}} (a) | eccentricity = 0.62767 (e) | period = 2.64 [[Julian year (astronomy)|yr]] (963.04 [[Julian year (astronomy)|d]]) | inclination = 5.3847° (i) | asc_node = 244.33° (Ω) | mean_anomaly = 12.440[[Degree (angle)|°]] (M) | arg_peri = 254.07° (ω) | dimensions = ~63 meters
50–110 meters | abs_magnitude = 23.6 | mean_motion = {{Deg2DMS|0.37382|sup=ms}} /day (n) | uncertainty = 7 | moid = {{Convert|0.000169707|AU|km|abbr=on}} | jupiter_moid = {{Convert|1.99284|AU|Gm|abbr=on}} }} '''{{mp|2007 VE|191}}''' is a sub-kilometer [[asteroid]], classified as [[near-Earth asteroid]] of the [[Apollo asteroid|Apollo group]] that was listed on the [[Sentry Risk Table]]. == Description == It is estimated to be roughly 63 meters in diameter. In 2015 it was known to have a 1 in 63,000 chance of [[Impact event|impacting]] Earth on 27 November 2015. However, the [[Curve fitting|nominal]] best-fit orbit showed that {{mp|2007 VE|191}} would be roughly {{convert|0.5|AU|km mi|abbr=on|lk=on}} from Earth on 27 November 2015 with an [[apparent magnitude]] of roughly +25 in the [[constellation]] of [[Virgo (constellation)|Virgo]] about 50 degrees from the Sun, and the same nominal orbit gave a distance of closest approach to Earth of a little under 0.4 AU a few weeks earlier. It was removed from the Sentry Risk Table on 17 September 2015, but was still listed at [[NEODyS]] with odds of 1 in 3 million for 27 November 2015 during the approach window. {{mp|2007 VE|191}} was discovered on 15 November 2007 by the [[Mount Lemmon Survey]] at an apparent magnitude of 20 using a {{convert|1.5|m|in|adj=on|sp=us}} [[reflecting telescope]]. On 28 November 2007, it passed {{convert|0.0128|AU|km mi|abbr=on|lk=on}} from Earth. {{mp|2007 VE|191}} has an [[observation arc]] of 13 days with an [[Uncertainty Parameter U|uncertainty parameter]] of 7, which means its orbit is poorly constrained. {{mp|2007 VE|191}} was last observed on 28 November 2007. By 1 December 2007, the asteroid had faded to below magnitude 25. With an [[Absolute magnitude#Solar System bodies (H)|absolute magnitude]] of 23.6, {{mp|2007 VE|191}} is about 50–110 meters in diameter. == References == {{Reflist|refs= {{cite web |type=last observation: 2007-11-28; [[Observation arc|arc]]: 13 days |title=JPL Small-Body Database Browser: (2007 VE191) |publisher=[[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] |url=http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=2007VE191 |accessdate=30 March 2016}} {{cite web |title=MPEC 2007-W05 : 2007 VE191 |publisher=[[IAU Minor Planet Center]] |date=2007-11-16 |url=http://www.minorplanetcenter.org/mpec/K07/K07W05.html |accessdate=2014-12-15}} (K07VJ1E) {{cite web |type=last observation: 2007-11-28; [[Observation arc|arc]]: 13 days |title=JPL Close-Approach Data: (2007 VE191) |url=http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=2007VE191;cad=1#cad |accessdate=2014-12-15}} {{cite web |title=Absolute Magnitude (H) |publisher=NASA/JPL |url=http://neo.jpl.nasa.gov/glossary/h.html |accessdate=2014-12-15}} {{cite web |title=Earth Impact Risk Summary: 2007 VE191 |publisher=NASA/JPL Near-Earth Object Program Office |url=http://neo.jpl.nasa.gov/risk/2007ve191.html |accessdate=2014-12-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150905192052/http://neo.jpl.nasa.gov/risk/2007ve191.html |archivedate=September 5, 2015 }} ([[Palermo Technical Impact Hazard Scale|PS]]=–2.47) {{cite web |title=2007VE191 Ephemerides for 1 October 2007 through 4 December 2007 |publisher=[[NEODyS]] (Near Earth Objects – Dynamic Site) |url=http://newton.dm.unipi.it/neodys/index.php?pc=1.1.3.1&n=2007VE191&oc=500&y0=2007&m0=10&d0=1&h0=0&mi0=0&y1=2007&m1=12&d1=4&h1=0&mi1=0&ti=1.0&tiu=days |accessdate=2014-12-15}} {{cite web |title=2007VE191 Ephemerides for 1 September 2015 through 10 December 2015 |publisher=[[NEODyS]] (Near Earth Objects – Dynamic Site) |url=http://newton.dm.unipi.it/neodys/index.php?pc=1.1.3.1&n=2007VE191&oc=500&y0=2015&m0=9&d0=1&h0=0&mi0=0&y1=2015&m1=12&d1=10&h1=0&mi1=0&ti=1.0&tiu=days |accessdate=2014-12-15}} {{cite web |title=Date/Time Removed |publisher=NASA/JPL Near-Earth Object Program Office |url=http://neo.jpl.nasa.gov/risk/removed.html |accessdate=2015-10-19}} {{cite web |title=NEODyS Impactor Table for 2007VE191 |publisher=[[NEODyS]] (Near Earth Objects – Dynamic Site) |url=http://newton.dm.unipi.it/neodys/index.php?pc=1.1.2&n=2007VE191 |accessdate=2015-10-19}} ([[Palermo Technical Impact Hazard Scale|PS]]=–4.87) }} == External links == * {{JPL small body}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} {{2015 in space}} {{Planetary defense}} {{Small Solar System bodies}} {{DEFAULTSORT:2007 VE191}} {{Infobox planet | minorplanet = yes | background = #FFC2E0 | name = 3200 Phaethon | image = PIA22185.gif | image_size = 270 | caption = Radar image of 3200 Phaethon taken by Arecibo, December 17, 2017 | discoverer = [[Simon F. Green|Simon Green]] and
[[John K. Davies]]{{\}}[[IRAS]] | discovered = October 11, 1983 | named_after = [[Phaethon|Phaëthon]] | mp_category = {{unbulleted list| [[Apollo asteroid]]|[[Potentially hazardous asteroid]]|[[Mercury-crosser asteroid]]|[[Venus-crosser asteroid]]|[[Earth-crosser asteroid]]|[[Mars-crosser asteroid]]}} | mpc_name = (3200) Phaethon | alt_names = 1983 TB | orbit_ref = | epoch = 2017-Sep-04 ([[Julian day|JD]] 2458000.5) | uncertainty = 0 | observation_arc = {{convert|12464|days|years}} | aphelion = {{Convert|2.4025|AU|e6km|sigfig=3|abbr=unit|lk=on}} | perihelion = {{Convert|0.13991|AU|e6km|sigfig=3|abbr=unit}} | semimajor = {{Convert|1.2712|AU|e6km|sigfig=3|abbr=unit}} | eccentricity = 0.88994 | period = {{convert|523.5|days|years}} | avg_speed = {{convert|19.9|km/s|mph|abbr=on}} | inclination = 22.253° | asc_node = 265.23° | mean_anomaly = 261.42° | mean_motion = {{Deg2DMS|0.68767950029|sup=ms}}{{\}}day | arg_peri = 322.17° | satellites = | moid = {{Convert|0.01945|AU|e6km|sigfig=3|abbr=unit}} | venus_moid = {{nowrap| {{Convert|0.0425|AU|e6km|sigfig=3|abbr=unit}} }} | jupiter_moid = {{Convert|2.7361|AU|e6km|sigfig=3|abbr=unit}} | tisserand = 4.511 | dimensions = {{convert|3.6|mi|km|1|order=flip|abbr=on}} | mass = | density = | rotation = {{Convert|3.604|hours|days|lk=on}} | albedo = {{val|0.1066|0.011}} | spectral_type = [[B-type asteroid]] | abs_magnitude = 14.6 | magnitude = 10.7 (2017-Dec-14) }} '''3200 Phaethon''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|f|eɪ|.|ə|θ|ɒ|n}} {{Respell|FAY|ə-thon}}, sometimes incorrectly spelled '''Phaeton'''), [[provisional designation in astronomy|provisional designation]] {{nowrap|'''1983 TB'''}}, is an [[Apollo asteroid]] with an orbit that brings it closer to the [[Sun]] than any other [[Minor planet#Naming|named asteroid]] (though there are numerous unnamed asteroids with smaller perihelia, such as {{mpl|(137924) 2000 BD|19}}). For this reason, it was named after the [[Greek mythology|Greek myth]] of [[Phaethon|Phaëthon]], son of the sun god [[Helios]]. It is {{convert|3.6|mi|km|1|order=flip|abbr=on}} in [[diameter]] and is the parent body of the [[Geminids]] [[meteor shower]] of mid-December. With an [[observation arc]] of 30+ years, it has a very well [[Orbit determination|determined orbit]]. The 2017 Earth approach distance of about 10 million km was known with an accuracy of ±40 km. == Discovery == Phaethon was the first asteroid to be discovered using images from a spacecraft. [[Simon F. Green]] and [[John K. Davies]] discovered it in images from October 11, 1983, while searching [[Infrared Astronomical Satellite]] (IRAS) data for moving objects. It was formally announced on October 14 in IAUC 3878 along with optical confirmation by [[Charles T. Kowal]], who reported it to be asteroidal in appearance. Its provisional designation was {{nowrap|1983 TB}}, and it later received the numerical designation and name {{nowrap|3200 Phaethon}} in 1985. == Orbital characteristics == [[File:3200 Phaethon orbit dec 2017.png|thumb|left|The elliptical orbit of 3200 Phaethon crosses the orbits of Mars, Earth, Venus and Mercury]] Phaethon is categorized as an [[Apollo asteroid]], as its orbital [[semi-major axis]] is greater than that of the [[Earth]]'s at {{convert|1.27|AU|e6km+e6mi|sigfig=3|abbr=unit|lk=in}}. It is also suspected to be a member of the [[Pallas family]] of asteroids. Its most remarkable distinction is that it approaches the Sun closer than any other named asteroid: its [[perihelion]] is only {{convert|0.14|AU|e6km+e6mi|sigfig=3|abbr=unit}} — less than half of [[Mercury (planet)|Mercury]]'s perihelial distance. It is a [[List of Mercury-crossing minor planets|Mercury-]], [[List of Venus-crossing minor planets|Venus-]], [[List of Earth-crossing minor planets|Earth-]], and [[List of Mars-crossing minor planets|Mars-crosser]] as a result of its high orbital eccentricity. The surface temperature at perihelion could reach around {{convert|1025|K|C F|-1}}. Phaethon is a possible candidate for detecting [[General relativity|general relativistic]] and/or solar [[oblateness]] effects in its orbital motion due to the frequent close approaches to the Sun. === Potentially hazardous asteroid === Phaethon is categorized as a [[potentially hazardous asteroid]] (PHA), but that does not mean there is a near-term threat of an impact. It is a potentially hazardous asteroid merely as a result of its size ([[Absolute magnitude#Solar System bodies (H)|absolute magnitude]] {{nowrap|''H'' ≤ 22}}) and Earth [[minimum orbit intersection distance]] {{nowrap|(''Earth MOID'' ≤ 0.05 AU}}). The Earth minimum orbit intersection distance (E-MOID) is {{cvt|0.01945|AU|abbr=on}}, which is defined by the shortest distance between the orbit of Phaethon and the orbit of Earth. With a 30+ year observation arc, the orbit of Phaethon is very well understood with very small uncertainties. Close approaches of Phaethon are well constrained for the next 400 years. {{Large near earth asteroid flybys 10LD}} == Physical characteristics == Phaethon is an asteroid with fairly unusual characteristics in that its orbit more closely resembles that of a [[comet]] than an asteroid; it has been referred to as a "[[rock comet]]". In recent studies performed by [[NASA]]'s [[STEREO]] spacecraft, dust tails have been observed, and in 2010, Phaethon was detected ejecting dust. It is possible that the Sun's heat is causing fractures similar to [[mudcrack]]s in a [[dry lake]] bed. Phaethon's composition fits the notion of its cometary origin; it is classified as a [[B-type asteroid]] because it is composed of dark material. Since its discovery, several other objects were found exhibiting mixed cometary and asteroidal features, such as [[7968 Elst–Pizarro|133P/Elst–Pizarro]]. == Meteor shower == Shortly after its discovery, [[Fred Whipple]] observed that the "orbital elements of 1983 TB shown on IAUC 3879 are virtually coincident with the mean orbital elements of 19 Geminid meteors photographed with the super-Schmidt meteor cameras". In other words, Phaethon is the long-sought parent body of the [[Geminids]] [[meteor shower]] of mid-December. == Close approaches == Phaethon approached to {{convert|0.120895|AU|km mi|abbr=on|lk=in}} of Earth on December 10, 2007, and was detected by [[radar astronomy|radar]] at [[Arecibo Observatory|Arecibo]]. When Phaethon came to perihelion in July 2009, it was found to be brighter than expected. During its approach, the [[STEREO]]-A spacecraft detected an unexpected brightening, roughly by a factor of two. === 2010 approach === [[File:Asteroid Phaethon 25dec2010 stack.jpg|thumb|left|300px|Phaethon imaged on December 25, 2010, with the {{nowrap|37-cm}} {{f/|14}} Rigel telescope at [[Winer Observatory]] by Marco Langbroek]] {{-}} === 2017 approach === On December 16, 2017, at 23:00 [[Universal Time|UT]], Phaethon passed {{convert|0.06893173|AU|km mi|abbr=on}} from Earth (27 [[lunar distance (astronomy)|lunar distance]]s). The Earth approach distance was known with a [[3-sigma]] accuracy of ±40 km.{{efn|name=JPL2014}} This was the best opportunity to date for radar observations by [[Goldstone Solar System Radar|Goldstone]] and [[Arecibo Observatory|Arecibo]], with a resolution of {{convert|75|m||abbr=off|sp=us|disp=x|/pixel (|/pixel)}}. The asteroid was bright enough to see in small telescopes, peaking at magnitude 10.8 between December 13–15 while dimming slightly to magnitude 11 on December 16 at closest approach. Arecibo made observations of Phaethon from December 15-19.{{cite web |url=https://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?feature=7030 |title=Arecibo Radar Returns with Asteroid Phaethon Images |publisher=NASA |first1=D. C. |last1=Agle |first2=Dwayne |last2=Brown |first3=Suraiya |last3=Farukhi |date=December 22, 2017 |accessdate=January 8, 2018}} It will not make an Earth approach closer than the 2017 passage until December 14, 2093, when it will pass {{convert|0.01981|AU|km mi|abbr=on}} from Earth. {{multiple image |total_width=800 |align=none | perrow = 1/2 |image1=3200 Phaethon skypath Dec 2017.png |caption1=Path of 3200 Phaethon in the sky during December 2017 |image2=Asteroid 3200 Phaethon (1983 TB).gif |caption2=Time lapse taken through a telescope in [[Riga]], [[Latvia]] (December 10, 2017) |image3=3200phaethonX100.gif |caption3=Phaethon at maximum angular velocity, December 15, 2017, 18:47:13–19:24:50 UTC }} == Notes == {{Notelist|refs= {{efn|name=JPL2014|1=In 2014, [https://archive.is/20141014161935/http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=3200;cad=1 JPL 374 (solution date 2014-Sep-12) ] showed a 2017 Earth approach distance with an accuracy of ±80 km. Math: (MAX−MIN) * [[Astronomical unit|AU]] / 2}} }} == References == {{reflist |refs= {{cite web |url=http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=3200;cad=1 |title=3200 Phaethon (1983 TB) |publisher=[[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] |work=[[JPL Small-Body Database]] |accessdate=December 13, 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171213001333/https://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=3200;cad=1 |archivedate=December 13, 2017|dead-url=no}} {{cite web |url=http://www.minorplanetcenter.net/db_search/show_object?object_id=3200 |title=(3200) Phaethon Orbit |publisher=[[Minor Planet Center]] |accessdate=November 28, 2017}} {{cite web |url=http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb_query.cgi?obj_group=all;obj_kind=ast;obj_numbered=all;OBJ_field=0;ORB_field=0;c1_group=ORB;c1_item=Bi;c1_op=%3C;c1_value=0.141;table_format=HTML;max_rows=100;format_option=comp;c_fields=AcBhBgBjBiBnBsCkCqAi;.cgifields=format_option;.cgifields=obj_kind;.cgifields=obj_group;.cgifields=obj_numbered;.cgifields=ast_orbit_class;.cgifields=table_format;.cgifields=com_orbit_class&query=1&c_sort=BiA |title=JPL Small-Body Database Search Engine — Constraints: asteroids and q < 0.141 (au) |website=[[JPL Small-Body Database]] |publisher=[[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] |access-date=September 5, 2011}} Take notice of the orbit condition number (the lower the number, the lower the orbit's uncertainty). {{cite news |url=https://voices.nationalgeographic.org/2010/10/12/geminids_meteor_shower_driven_by_exploding_clays/ |title=Exploding Clays Drive Geminids Sky Show? |work=National Geographic |first=Victoria |last=Jaggard |date=October 12, 2010 |accessdate=August 10, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170811104002/https://voices.nationalgeographic.org/2010/10/12/geminids_meteor_shower_driven_by_exploding_clays/ |archive-date=August 11, 2017 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} {{cite web |url=https://echo.jpl.nasa.gov/asteroids/Phaethon/Phaethon_planning.2017.html |title=Goldstone Radar Observations Planning: Asteroid 3200 Phaethon |publisher=NASA/JPL Asteroid Radar Research |first=Lance A. M. |last=Benner |date=2017 |accessdate=November 26, 2017}} {{cite web |url=https://science.nasa.gov/science-news/science-at-nasa/2007/03dec_asteroidshower |title=Asteroid Shower |publisher=[[NASA]] |series=Science@NASA |first=Tony |last=Phillips |date=December 3, 2007 |accessdate=April 4, 2017}} {{cite web |url=https://cneos.jpl.nasa.gov/about/neo_groups.html |title=NEO Groups |series=Near Earth Object Program |publisher=NASA |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161102020040/http://neo.jpl.nasa.gov/neo/groups.html |archivedate=November 2, 2016 |deadurl=no}} {{cite journal |title=Activity in Geminid Parent (3200) Phaethon |journal=[[The Astronomical Journal]] |last1=Jewitt |first1=David |last2=Li |first2=Jing |volume=140 |issue=5 |page=1519 |date=2010 |arxiv=1009.2710 |bibcode=2010AJ....140.1519J |doi=10.1088/0004-6256/140/5/1519}} {{cite journal |title=The Dust Tail of Asteroid (3200) Phaethon |journal=[[The Astrophysical Journal Letters]] |last1=Jewitt |first1=David |last2=Li |first2=Jing |last3=Agarwal |first3=Jessica |volume=771 |issue=2 |at=L36 |date=2013 |arxiv=1306.3741 |bibcode=2013ApJ...771L..36J |doi=10.1088/2041-8205/771/2/L36}} {{cite web |url=http://www.skymania.com/wp/2013/09/why-an-asteroid-is-crumbling-into-meteor-dust.html/ |title=Why an asteroid is crumbling into meteor dust |work=Skymania.com |first=Paul |last=Sutherland |date=September 10, 2013 |accessdate=September 10, 2013}} {{cite journal |title=1983 TB and the Geminid Meteors |journal=[[IAU Circular]] |last=Whipple |first=F. L. |editor-last=Marsden |editor-first=B. G. |volume=3881 |at=1 |date=October 25, 1983 |bibcode=1983IAUC.3881....1W}} {{cite web |url=http://www.ast.cam.ac.uk/~jds/news09.htm |title=Comet Section: 2009 News |publisher=British Astronomical Association |first=Jonathan |last=Shanklin |date=2009 |accessdate=September 20, 2009}} {{cite journal |title=(3200) Phaethon |journal=[[IAU Circular]] |author1=Battams |first1=K. |last2=Watson {{Infobox zoo | zoo_name = Arenal Eco Zoo | image =Lac Arenal Costa Rica Barrage.JPG | image_width = 250px | image_caption =Lake Arenal | logo_width = 250px | date_opened = | location = [[Alajuela Province]]
{{CRI}} | area = | coordinates = {{coord|10.4248187|-84.752048|display=inline}} | num_animals = 70+ species | num_species = | website = [http://www.arenalecozoo.com/ ArenalEcoZoo.com/] }} The '''Arenal Eco Zoo''' is a nature center located in western [[Alajuela Province]], [[Costa Rica]].{{cite web | url =http://www.houstoniamag.com/articles/2016/6/23/5-fun-things-to-do-in-costa-rica | title =5 Fun Things to Do in Costa Rica If You Only Have a Few Days | last =Wiatrak | first =Bill | date =23 Jun 2016 | website = [[Houstonia (magazine)|Houstonia]] | publisher = | access-date =21 Sep 2016 | quote = }} It is located across [[Lake Arenal]], west of [[Arenal Volcano National Park]], right at the border between Alajuela and [[Guanacaste Province]]s. ==Description== The center has a number of educational exhibits, a wide variety of more than 70 snake species, reptiles are also on display, as are more than 30 species of frogs, and a display of spiders and insects. The zoo also organizes naturalist trips and tours to view of over 40 species of butterfly into the surrounding jungle to emulate that of the natural habitats of the species.{{cite web | url =https://www.independent.co.uk/travel/americas/costa-rica-family-and-other-animals-9122078.html | title =Costa Rica: Your family and other animals | last = | first = | date =11 Feb 2014 | website = [[The Independent]] | publisher = | access-date =21 Sep 2016 | quote = }} The center also has many arachnid and insect species including [[tarantula]]s, [[rhinoceros beetle]]s and giant 5 inch [[caterpillar]]s. The zoo was founded by Victor Hugo Quesada and his wife Ofelia in 2000. Its original name was El Serpentario Zoologico del Castillo. Today it is known as the Arenal Eco Zoo.{{Cite web|url=https://www.costarica.com/attractions/arenal-ecozoo|title=Arenal EcoZoo|website=Costa Rica|language=en-US|access-date=2018-04-12}} == See also == * [[List of zoos by country]]: [[List of zoos by country#Costa Rica|Costa Rica zoos]] ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Museums in Costa Rica]] [[Category:Nature centers]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Puntarenas Province]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Puntarenas Province]] {{-}} {{CostaRica-stub}} {{Zoo-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=May 2013}}
{{Infobox company |name = BETTERY Inc. |type = [[private company|Private]] |logo = File:BETTERYInc logo.jpg |foundation = 2011 |location_city = [[Tacoma, Washington]] |location_country = USA |key_people = Shem Zakem, President |industry = [[Sustainable energy]] |products = [reusable batteries and Swap Stations] |subsid = |homepage = [http://www.betteryinc.com] }}
'''BETTERY Inc.''' was a privately held company based in Portland, Oregon. It provided a retail store-based reusable battery exchange service to consumers. BETTERY kiosks or "Swap Stations" allow consumers to buy ready to use reusable AA or AAA batteries that can be used just like any other single use battery. Once drained, the batteries can be swapped for a fully tested and charged replacement. The company previously had placed five kiosks at [[Whole Foods Market]] locations in the Pacific Northwest and placed five additional kiosks at Whole Foods and Safeway stores in Seattle and Portland. The BETTERY brand was sold in 2014 to Green Box Batteries, LLC, a Tacoma, WA privately held company. Green Box Batteries, LLC has re-launched the BETTERY brand with a focus on bringing batteries to the world of subscription services much like Netflix did for DVD rentals.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sustainablebusinessoregon.com/articles/2013/04/bettery-goes-for-the-whole-shebang.html | title=BETTERY goes for the Whole shebang | publisher=Portland Business Journal | date= 2013-04-03|accessdate=2012-04-15}}</ref>
== Environmental Impact == Batteries account for >1% of waste poundage, but 88% of mercury, 52% of cadmium, and in total they account for 50-70% of all heavy metal contaminants in landfills including Zinc, Manganese, Lead, Nickel, Cobalt, Cadmium, Arsenic, and Mercury depending on the battery chemistry mix in a given landfill location. By using a reusable battery swap service, battery use has up to 30 times less impact on air pollutants (such as Carbon, Nitrogen, and Methane gases) than disposable batteries. That is equivalent to driving a car 1,243 miles less each year per consumer.
By making it easier for consumers to use reusable battery technology, The BETTERY brand reduces the volume of batteries that are thrown away in the U.S. every year. Approximately 90 percent of portable batteries manufactured in the US are alkaline dry cells with a global annual production exceeding 10 billion units. Today, the majority of these batteries end up in landfills.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://xa.yimg.com/kq/groups/1896863/738588603/name/MIT%20Battery%20LCA%20by%20NEMA%20Final.pdf | title=Life Cycle Impacts of Alkaline Batteries with a Focus on End-of-Life | publisher=National Electrical Manufacturers Association | date= 2011-02-01|accessdate=2012-04-15}}</ref>
Each BETTERY reusable battery can be swapped and reused up to a thousand times before it is recycled back into the manufacturing stream.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.recyclinginternational.com/recycling-news/7006/e-waste-and-batteries/united-states/better-battery-recycling-bettery | title=Better battery recycling with BETTERY? | publisher=Recycling International | date=2013-04-12|accessdate=2012-04-15}}</ref> Consumers can use the BETTERY kiosk to drop off traditional single-use batteries, where they will be recycled. The contents of recycled batteries can be salvaged to make metal and other raw materials.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.opb.org/news/blog/ecotrope/what-happens-to-recycled-batteries/ | title=What Happens to Recycled Batteries? | publisher=OPB News | date=2013-04-04|accessdate=2012-04-15}}</ref>
== History == Founded in 2011 with the mission to reduce waste by utilizing the latest advancements in reusable battery technology, BETTERY belongs to the movement of companies with sustainability at its core. With a veteran team of executives and advisers from major battery, kiosk and high tech companies, BETTERY is poised to reinvent the portable power industry.
==See also== * [[List of companies based in Oregon]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.betteryinc.com Bettery Inc.]
[[Category:Sustainable energy]] [[Category:Privately held companies based in Oregon]] [[Category:Companies based in Portland, Oregon]] [[Category:Companies established in 2011]] [[Category:2011 establishments in Portland, Oregon]]

revision.comment: Rescuing orphaned refs ("livescience" from [[La Garita Caldera]])
revision.text:
{{other uses}} [[File:Mount Mazama eruption timeline.PNG|thumb|right|[[Mount Mazama]]'s eruption timeline, an example of caldera formation]]
A '''caldera''' is a large [[cauldron]]-like hollow that forms following the evacuation of a [[magma chamber]]/reservoir. When large volumes of magma are erupted over a short time, structural support for the crust above the magma chamber is lost. The ground surface then collapses downward into the partially emptied magma chamber, leaving a massive depression at the surface (from one to dozens of kilometers in diameter). Although sometimes described as a [[Volcanic crater|crater]], the feature is actually a type of [[sinkhole]], as it is formed through subsidence and collapse rather than an explosion or impact. Only seven known caldera-forming collapses have occurred since the start of the 20th century, most recently at [[Bárðarbunga]] volcano in Iceland.<ref>Gudmundsson, M.T. et al. (2014) Graduale caldera collapse at Bárðarbunga volcano Iceland, regulated by lateral magma outflow, Science, 15.</ref>
== Etymology == The word comes from [[Spanish language|Spanish]] ''{{wiktes|caldera}}'', and [[Latin]] ''{{wiktla|caldaria}}'', meaning "cooking pot". In some texts the English term ''cauldron'' is also used. The term ''caldera'' was introduced into the geological vocabulary by the German geologist [[Leopold von Buch]] when he published his memoirs of his 1815 visit to the [[Canary Islands]],{{refn|group=note|name=note 1|Leopold von Buch's book ''Physical Description of the Canary Isles'' was published in 1825}} where he first saw the Las Cañadas caldera on [[Tenerife]], with Montaña [[Teide]] dominating the landscape, and then the [[Caldera de Taburiente]] on [[La Palma]].
==Caldera formation== [[File:Origin of volcanic caldera via analogue model.gif|thumb|left|Animation of analogue experiment showing origin of volcanic caldera in box filled with flour.]] [[File:Toba zoom.jpg|thumb|left|[[Landsat]] image of [[Lake Toba]], on the island of [[Sumatra]], [[Indonesia]] (100 km/62 mi long and 30 km/19 mi wide, one of the world's largest calderas). A [[resurgent dome]] formed the island of [[Samosir]].]]
A collapse is triggered by the emptying of the [[magma chamber]] beneath the volcano, sometimes as the result of a large explosive [[volcano|volcanic eruption]] (see [[1815 eruption of Mount Tambora|Tambora]] in 1815), but also during effusive eruptions on the flanks of a volcano (see [[Piton de la Fournaise]] in 2007) or in a connected fissure system (see [[Bárðarbunga]] in 2014–2015). If enough [[magma]] is ejected, the emptied chamber is unable to support the weight of the volcanic edifice above it. A roughly circular [[Fracture (geology)|fracture]], the "ring fault", develops around the edge of the chamber. Ring fractures serve as feeders for fault [[intrusion]]s which are also known as [[Ring dike|ring dykes]]. Secondary volcanic vents may form above the ring fracture. As the magma chamber empties, the center of the volcano within the ring fracture begins to collapse. The collapse may occur as the result of a single cataclysmic eruption, or it may occur in stages as the result of a series of eruptions. The total area that collapses may be hundreds or thousands of square kilometers.
===Mineralization=== Some calderas are known to host rich [[ore deposit]]s. One of the world's best-preserved [[Mineralization (geology)|mineralized]] calderas is the [[Sturgeon Lake Caldera]] in [[northwestern Ontario]], Canada, which formed during the [[Neoarchean]] [[Era (geology)|era]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.d.umn.edu/prc/workshops/S08workshop.html |title=UMD: Precambrian Research Center |publisher=University of Minnesota, Duluth |date= |accessdate=2014-03-20}}</ref> about 2,700 million years ago.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.d.umn.edu/~rmorton/ronshome/Volcanoes/calderas.html |title=Caldera Volcanoes |author= Ron Morton |publisher=University of Minnesota, Duluth |date=|accessdate=2015-07-03}}</ref>
===Explosive caldera eruptions=== {{Details|Explosive eruption}} If the [[magma]] is rich in [[silica]], the caldera is often filled in with [[ignimbrite]], [[tuff]], [[rhyolite]], and other [[igneous rock]]s. Silica-rich magma has a high [[viscosity]], and therefore does not flow easily like [[basalt]]. As a result, gases tend to become trapped at high pressure within the magma. When the magma approaches the surface of the Earth, the rapid off-loading of overlying material causes the trapped gases to decompress rapidly, thus triggering explosive destruction of the magma and spreading [[volcanic ash]] over wide areas. Further [[lava]] flows may be erupted.
If volcanic activity continues, the center of the caldera may be uplifted in the form of a ''[[resurgent dome]]'' such as is seen at [[Galán|Cerro Galán]], [[Lake Toba]], [[Yellowstone Caldera|Yellowstone]], etc., by subsequent intrusion of magma. A ''silicic'' or ''[[Rhyolite|rhyolitic]] caldera'' may erupt hundreds or even thousands of cubic kilometers of material in a single event. Even small caldera-forming eruptions, such as [[Krakatoa]] in 1883 or [[Mount Pinatubo]] in 1991, may result in significant local destruction and a noticeable drop in temperature around the world. Large calderas may have even greater effects.
When Yellowstone Caldera last erupted some 650,000 years ago, it released about 1,000 km<sup>3</sup> of material (as measured in dense rock equivalent (DRE)), covering a substantial part of [[North America]] in up to two metres of debris. By comparison, when [[Mount St. Helens]] erupted in 1980, it released ~1.2 km<sup>3</sup> (DRE) of ejecta. The ecological effects of the eruption of a large caldera can be seen in the record of the [[Lake Toba]] eruption in [[Indonesia]].
====Toba==== {{Main|Lake Toba|Toba catastrophe theory}}
About 74,000 years ago, this Indonesian volcano released about {{convert|2800|km3}} [[dense-rock equivalent]] of ejecta. This was the largest known eruption during the ongoing [[Quaternary]] period (the last 2.6 million years) and the largest known explosive eruption during the last 25 million years. In the late 1990s, [[anthropologist]] Stanley Ambrose<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.anthro.illinois.edu/people/ambrose | title=Stanley Ambrose page | publisher=University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign | accessdate=20 March 2014}}</ref> proposed that a [[volcanic winter]] induced by this eruption reduced the human population to about 2,000–20,000 individuals, resulting in a [[population bottleneck]]. More recently, [[Lynn Jorde]] and [[Henry Harpending]] proposed that the human species was reduced to approximately 5,000-10,000 people.<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/science/horizon/1999/supervolcanoes_script.shtml Supervolcanoes], [[BBC2]], 3 February 2000</ref> There is no direct evidence, however, that either theory is correct, and there is no evidence for any other animal decline or extinction, even in environmentally sensitive species.<ref>{{cite journal | last1=Gathorne-Hardy | first1=F. J.| last2=Harcourt-Smith | first2=W. E. H. | title=The super-eruption of Toba, did it cause a human bottleneck? | journal=[[Journal of Human Evolution]] | year=2003 | volume=45 | issue=3 | pages=227–30 | doi=10.1016/S0047-2484(03)00105-2 | pmid=14580592}}</ref> There is evidence that human habitation continued in [[India]] after the eruption.<ref>{{cite journal | last1=Petraglia | first1=M. | last2=Korisettar | first2=R. | last3=Boivin | first3=N. | last4=Clarkson | first4=C. | last5=Ditchfield | first5=P. | last6=Jones | first6=S. | last7=Koshy | first7=J. | last8=Lahr | first8=M. M. | last9=Oppenheimer | first9=C. | last10=Pyle | first10=D. | last11=Roberts | first11=R. | last12=Schwenninger | first12=J. L. | last13=Arnold | first13=L. | last14=White | first14=K. | title=Middle Paleolithic Assemblages from the Indian Subcontinent Before and After the Toba Super-Eruption | journal=Science | year=2007 | volume=317 | issue=5834 | pages=114–16 | doi=10.1126/science.1141564 | pmid=17615356 | bibcode=2007Sci...317..114P}}</ref>
Eruptions forming even larger calderas are known, especially [[La Garita Caldera]] in the [[San Juan Mountains]] of [[Colorado]], where the {{convert|5000|km3}} [[Fish Canyon Tuff]] was blasted out in eruptions about 27.8 million years ago.<ref name=livescience> {{cite web | url=http://www.livescience.com/11113-biggest-volcanic-eruption.html|title=What's the Biggest Volcanic Eruption Ever? | publisher=livescience.com | date=November 10, 2010 | accessdate=2014-02-01}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = The 36–18 Ma Indian Peak–Caliente ignimbrite field and calderas, southeastern Great Basin, USA: Multicyclic super-eruptions|last = Best|first = MG|date = 2013|journal = Geosphere|doi = 10.1130/GES00902.1|pmid = |access-date = |bibcode = 2013Geosp...9..864B}}</ref>
At some points in [[geological time]], rhyolitic calderas have appeared in distinct clusters. The remnants of such clusters may be found in places such as the San Juan Mountains of Colorado (formed during the [[Oligocene]], [[Miocene]], and [[Pliocene]] epochs) or the [[Saint Francois Mountain Range]] of [[Missouri]] (erupted during the [[Proterozoic]] eon).<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kisvarsanyi|first=Eva|year=1981|title=Geology of the Precambrian St. Francois terrane, southeastern Missouri|url=https://searchworks.stanford.edu/view/1246541|journal=Report of investigations (Missouri Geological Survey) no. 64|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref>
[[File:La Cumbre - ISS.JPG|thumb|right|Satellite photograph of the summit caldera on [[Fernandina Island]] in the [[Galápagos Islands|Galápagos]] [[archipelago]].]] [[File:Nemrut Caldera aerial.jpg|thumb|right|Oblique aerial photo of Nemrut Caldera, Van Lake, Eastern Turkey]]
===Non-explosive calderas=== [[File:Iss038e012569, Caldera Sollipulli.jpg|thumb|Sollipulli Caldera, located in central Chile near the border with Argentina, filled with ice. The volcano is in the southern Andes Mountains within Chile's Parque Nacional Villarica.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/IOTD/view.php?id=82676 | title=EO | website=Earthobservatory.nasa.gov | accessdate=20 March 2014}}</ref>]]
Some volcanoes, such as the large [[shield volcano]]es [[Kīlauea]] and [[Mauna Loa]] on the island of [[Hawaii (island)|Hawaii]], form calderas in a different fashion. The magma feeding these volcanoes is [[basalt]], which is silica poor. As a result, the magma is much less [[Viscosity|viscous]] than the magma of a rhyolitic volcano, and the magma chamber is drained by large lava flows rather than by explosive events. The resulting calderas are also known as subsidence calderas and can form more gradually than explosive calderas. For instance, the caldera atop [[Fernandina Island]] collapsed in 1968 when parts of the caldera floor dropped {{convert|350|m}}.<ref name=gvp>{{cite gvp | vn=353010&vtab=Photos | title=Fernandina: Photo}}</ref>
==Extraterrestrial calderas== Since the early 1960s, it has been known that volcanism has occurred on other planets and moons in the [[Solar System]]. Through the use of manned and unmanned spacecraft, volcanism has been discovered on [[Venus]], [[Mars]], the [[Moon]], and [[Io (moon)|Io]], a satellite of [[Jupiter]]. None of these worlds have [[plate tectonics]], which contributes approximately 60% of the Earth's volcanic activity (the other 40% is attributed to [[hotspot (geology)|hotspot]] volcanism).<ref name = "Wilson">{{Cite book | last = Parfitt | first = L. | author-link = | last2 = Wilson | first2 = L. | author2-link = | title = Fundamentals of Physical Volcanology | place = Malden, MA | publisher = [[Blackwell Publishing]]| date= Feb 19, 2008| edition = | chapter = Volcanism on Other Planets| chapterurl = | pages = 190–212| language = | url = http://google.com/books?id=ptpCiNkwLj8C&printsec=frontcover| doi = | id = | isbn = 978-0-632-05443-5 | mr = | zbl = | jfm = | oclc = 173243845| postscript =.}}</ref> Caldera structure is similar on all of these planetary bodies, though the size varies considerably. The average caldera diameter on Venus is 68 km. The average caldera diameter on Io is close to 40 km, and the mode is 6 km; [[Tvashtar Paterae]] is likely the largest caldera with a diameter of 290 km. The average caldera diameter on Mars is 48 km, smaller than Venus. Calderas on Earth are the smallest of all planetary bodies and vary from 1.6 to 80 km as a maximum.<ref>Gudmundsson, A. (2008) ''Magma chamber geometry, fluid transport, local stresses and rock behaviour during collapse caldera formation'' in Gottsmann, J. and Marti, J. (editors) (2008) ''Caldera Volcanism: Analysis, Modelling and Response'', Amsterdam, Elsevier. p. 319, citing Lipman, P. (2000).</ref>
===The Moon=== The [[Moon]] has an outer shell of low-density crystalline rock that is a few hundred kilometers thick, which formed due to a rapid creation. The craters of the moon have been well preserved through time and were once thought to have been the result of extreme volcanic activity, but actually were formed by meteorites, nearly all of which took place in the first few hundred million years after the Moon formed. Around 500 million years afterward, the Moon's mantle was able to be extensively melted due to the decay of radioactive elements. Massive basaltic eruptions took place generally at the base of large impact craters. Also, eruptions may have taken place due to a magma reservoir at the base of the crust. This forms a dome, possibly the same morphology of a shield volcano where calderas universally are known to form.<ref name = "Wilson"/> Although caldera-like structures are rare on the Moon, they are not completely absent. The [[Compton–Belkovich Thorium Anomaly|Compton-Belkovich Volcanic Complex]] on the [[far side of the Moon]] is thought to be a caldera, possibly an [[Pyroclastic flow|ash-flow]] caldera.<ref name="Compton-Belkovich">{{cite journal|last1=Chauhan|first1=M.|last2=Bhattacharya|first2=S.|last3=Saran|first3=S.|last4=Chauhan|first4=P.|last5=Dagar|first5=A.|title=Compton–Belkovich Volcanic Complex (CBVC): An ash flow caldera on the Moon|journal=Icarus|date=2015|volume=253|pages=115–29|doi=10.1016/j.icarus.2015.02.024|bibcode=2015Icar..253..115C}}</ref>
===Mars=== {{Further|Volcanology of Mars}} The volcanic activity of [[Mars]] is concentrated in two major provinces: [[Tharsis]] and [[Elysium (volcanic province)|Elysium]]. Each province contains a series of giant shield volcanoes that are similar to what we see on Earth and likely are the result of mantle [[Hotspot (geology)|hot spots]]. The surfaces are dominated by lava flows, and all have one or more collapse calderas.<ref name = "Wilson"/> Mars has the largest volcano in the Solar System, [[Olympus Mons]], which is more than three times the height of Mount Everest, with a diameter of 520 km (323 miles). The summit of the mountain has six nested calderas.<ref>Philip's World Reference Atlas including Stars and Planets {{ISBN|0-7537-0310-6}} Publishing House Octopus publishing Group Ltd p. 9</ref>
===Venus=== {{Further|Volcanology of Venus}} Because there is no [[plate tectonics]] on [[Venus]], heat is mainly lost by conduction through the [[lithosphere]]. This causes enormous lava flows, accounting for 80% of Venus' surface area. Many of the mountains are large [[shield volcano]]es that range in size from 150–400 km in diameter and 2–4 km high. More than 80 of these large shield volcanoes have summit calderas averaging 60 km across.<ref name = "Wilson"/>
===Io=== {{Further|Volcanology of Io}} Io, unusually, is heated by solid flexing due to the [[Tidal force|tidal]] influence of [[Jupiter]] and Io's [[orbital resonance]] with neighboring large moons [[Europa (moon)|Europa]] and [[Ganymede (moon)|Ganymede]], which keeps its orbit slightly [[orbital eccentricity|eccentric]]. Unlike any of the planets mentioned, Io is continuously volcanically active. For example, the NASA ''[[Voyager 1]]'' and ''[[Voyager 2]]'' spacecraft detected nine erupting volcanoes while passing Io in 1979. Io has many calderas with diameters tens of kilometers across.<ref name = "Wilson"/>

revision.text:
{{Infobox protected area | name = Caribous-de-Val-d'Or Biodiversity Reserve | iucn_category = III | label = | photo = | location = | map = Quebec#Canada | map_caption = Location of Caribous-de-Val-d'Or Biodiversity Reserve | nearest_city = [[Val d'Or]] | coordinates = {{coords|47|58|00|N|77|41|00|W|display=inline, title}} | area = {{convert|434.19|km2|abbr=on}} | established = April 28, 2009 | visitation_num = | visitation_year = | governing_body = }}
'''Caribous-de-Val-d'Or Biodiversity Reserve''' ({{lang-fr|Réserve de biodiversité des Caribous-de-Val-d'Or}}) is a [[biodiversity reserve]] located in [[Abitibi-Témiscamingue]], [[Quebec]], [[Canada]], less than {{convert|20|km|abbr=on}} southeast of the city of [[Val d'Or]]. It was established on April 28, 2009.<ref>{{cite web|title=Réserve de biodiversité des Caribous-de-Val-d'Or|url=http://www.toponymie.gouv.qc.ca/ct/ToposWeb/Fiche.aspx?no_seq=394910|publisher=Commission de toponymie Quebec|language=French|accessdate=January 16, 2017}}</ref> The largest lake in the reserve is [[Sabourin Lake]]. With an area of {{convert|434.19|km|abbr=on}}, it is one of the largest protected areas in Quebec.
==Geography==
Caribous-de-Val-d'Or Biodiversity Reserve is located in Abitibi-Témiscamingue between latitudes 47°45'N and 48°02'N and between longitudes 77°22'W and 77°52'W less than {{convert|20|km|abbr=on}} southeast of Val d'Or. It can be accessed via a major forest road (Chemin Twin) and other forest roads from the north and east via [[Quebec Route 117]]. The southwest is bordered by the [[Caribous-de-Jourdan Ecological Reserve]] and part of the southeast is bordered by the [[Ottawa River]].<ref name="Val">{{cite web|title=Réserve de biodiversité des Caribous-de-Val-d'Or|url=http://www.mddelcc.gouv.qc.ca/biodiversite/reserves-bio/caribou/PCF_caribous_ang.pdf|publisher=[[Ministry of Sustainable Development, Environment and Parks (Quebec)|MDDELCC]]|format=PDF|accessdate=January 16, 2017}}</ref>
==Purpose==
The purpose of the reserve is to protect the [[caribou]] (there are currently around 30 within the reserve),<ref name="Val" /> which was once abundant in southern Quebec. The population of caribou within the reserve is one of the most threatened in Quebec, due to a variety of factors, such as its size, fragmentation, isolation and predation by the [[wolf]]. Although the reserve itself has an area of {{convert|434.19|km2|abbr=on}}, the habitat used by the caribou extends to between {{convert|1200|km2|abbr=on}} and {{convert|2000|km2|abbr=on}}.<ref name="Val d'Or">{{cite web|title=La Réserve de biodiversité des Caribous-de-Val-d'Or|url=http://www.humanima.com/decouverte/fr/article/la-reserve-de-biodiversite-des-caribous-de-val|publisher=Humanima|language=French|accessdate=January 16, 2017}}</ref>
==Flora and fauna==
Other wildlife within the reserve include black lichen peatlands and spruce forests, which are essential.<ref name="Val d'Or" /> There are also 51 species of bird, with 43 of them nesting in the reserve; there are also cranes and [[sharp-tailed grouse]]s.<ref name="Val d'Or" />
There is a huge diversity of mammals, including the [[American black bear|black bear]], [[North American porcupine]], wolf, [[lynx]], [[raccoon]], [[coyote]], [[moose]] and caribou. Within Sabourin Lake, there are twelve species of fish.<ref name="Val" />
==Protective measures==
There have been protective measures within the reserve to preserve the caribou population, such as the hunting and trapping of their main predators such as black bears and wolves. The number of moose is also being reduced.<ref name="Val d'Or" />
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Protected Areas of Quebec}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Caribous-de-Val-d'Or Biodiversity Reserve}} [[Category:IUCN Category III]] [[Category:Protected areas established in 2009]] [[Category:Protected areas of Abitibi-Témiscamingue]]

'''ChinaSat''' ({{zh|s=中星|p=Zhōngxīng}}) is the [[brand name]] of [[communications satellite]]s operated by [[China Satellite Communications]]. ==History== In 2007 a joint venture [[China Direct Broadcast Satellite]] was formed to runs the brand ChinaSat.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chinadbsat.com.cn/english/profile.asp?id=4|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707020359/http://www.chinadbsat.com.cn/english/profile.asp?id=4|dead-url=yes|archive-date=7 July 2011|title=Overview|work=Corporate Profile|publisher=China DBSAT|accessdate=11 July 2010}} </ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chinabond.com.cn/resource/1472/1488/1505/18682/21000/18612/111632/112699/7026291/12789863000731934918116.pdf|title=2007 Annual Report|date=2008|access-date=25 July 2017|work=CASC|publisher=chinabond.com.cn|language=Chinese}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.spacedaily.com/reports/First_Chinese_Satellite_Conglomerate_Beams_Into_Operation_999.html|title=First Chinese Satellite Conglomerate Beams Into Operation|publisher=Space Daily|date=2 January 2008|accessdate=11 July 2010|work=Xinhua News Agency}}</ref> It was a joint venture of state-owned companies [[China Satellite Communications]], [[China Orient Telecommunications Satellite]] and [[Sino Satellite Communications]]. The latter was controlled by [[China Aerospace Science and Technology Corporation]] (CASC). However, China Satellite Communications was changed from a direct subsidiary of the [[State-owned Assets Supervision and Administration Commission of the State Council]] (SASAC) to a direct subsidiary of CASC in 2009, making the joint venture was dissolved and Sino Satellite Communications became a subsidiary of China Satellite Communications.
The brand ChinaSat was previously operated by China Telecommunications Broadcast Satellite Corporation, which was owned by China's Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications.<ref> {{cite web | url = http://www.fas.org/spp/guide/china/comm/chinasat.htm | title = Zhongxing / Chinasat | publisher = Federation of American Scientists | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070703190051/http://www.fas.org/spp/guide/china/comm/chinasat.htm | archivedate = 2007-07-03 | df = }} </ref> China Telecommunications Broadcast Satellite Corporation was merged with other state-owned companies to form [[China Satellite Communications|China Satellite Communications Corporation]] circa 2000.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gov.cn/gongbao/content/2000/content_60405.htm|title=关于组建中国卫星通信集团公司有关问题的批复|date=16 June 2000|access-date=26 July 2017|publisher=State Council of the People's Republic of China|language=Chinese}}</ref>
Satellites formerly operated by Sino Satellite Communications and China Orient Telecommunications Satellite were renamed with ChinaSat designations following the acquisition of China Satellite Communications by CASC. ChinaStar 1 became ChinaSat 5A,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chinasatcom.com/n782704/c791021/content.html|title=中星5A|publisher=China Satellite Communications|date=2 December 2014|accessdate=25 July 2017|language=Chinese}}</ref> SinoSat 1 became ChinaSat 5B,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chinasatcom.com/satellite.asp?theName=%D6%D0%D0%C75B&id=2|title=中星5B|publisher=China Satellite Communications|accessdate=11 July 2010}} {{dead link|date=July 2017}}</ref> and SinoSat 3 became ChinaSat 5C.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chinasatcom.com/satellite.asp?theName=%D6%D0%D0%C75C&id=3|title=中星5C|publisher=China Satellite Communications|accessdate=11 July 2010}} {{dead link|date=July 2017}}</ref>
==Satellites== === ChinaSat 2A === ChinaSat 2A was launched in 2012.<ref>[http://www.zarya.info/Diaries/Launches/Launches.php?year=2012#067 2012 - Launches to Orbit and Beyond]</ref> ===ChinaSat 5A=== ChinaSat 5A was launched in 1998, formerly known as ChinaStar 1.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://space.skyrocket.de/doc_sdat/zhongwei-1.htm|title=Zhongwei 1 (ChinaStar 1) → ZX 5A (ChinaSat 5A) → APStar 9A|date=2 June 2017|access-date=26 July 2017|publisher=skyrocket.de}}</ref> It was leased to [[China Satellite Communications]]'s subsidiary [[APT Satellite Holdings]] and renamed to Apstar 9A on 9 January 2014.<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.hkexnews.hk/listedco/listconews/SEHK/2014/0109/LTN20140109316.pdf|title=VOLUNTARY ANNOUNCEMENT RENAMING CHINASAT 5A TO APSTAR 9A|date=9 January 2014|access-date=26 July 2017|publisher=APT Satellite Holdings}}</ref>
===ChinaSat 5B=== ChinaSat 5B was launched in 1998, formerly known as Sinosat 1. It was sold to [[Pasifik Satelit Nusantara]] in 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://space.skyrocket.de/doc_sdat/sinosat-1.htm|title=Sinosat 1 (Xinnuo 1, Intelsat APR 1) → ZX 5B (ChinaSat 5B) → PSN 5|date=2 June 2017|access-date=26 July 2017|publisher=skyrocket.de}}</ref> ===ChinaSat 5C=== ChinaSat 5C was launched in 2007, formerly known as SinoSat 3. It was leased to [[Eutelsat]] in 2011 (as [[Eutelsat 3A]] and then [[Eutelsat 8 West D]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://space.skyrocket.de/doc_sdat/sinosat-3.htm|title=Sinosat 3 (Xinnuo 3) → ZX 5C (ChinaSat 5C) → Eutelsat 3A → Eutelsat 8 West D|date=2 June 2017|access-date=26 July 2017|publisher=skyrocket.de}}</ref> ===ChinaSat 5D=== ChinaSat 5D was launched in 1996, formerly known as Apstar 1A.<ref name=Apstar1>{{cite web|url=http://space.skyrocket.de/doc_sdat/apstar-1.htm|title=APStar 1, 1A / ZX 5D, 5E (ChinaSat 5D, 5E)|date=2 June 2017|access-date=26 July 2017|publisher=skyrocket.de}}</ref> It was placed in [[geosynchronous orbit]] at a longitude of 51.5° East circa 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chinasatcom.com/cn/News_Info.aspx?m=20101221173706030603&n=20110321091418060015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110407020347/http://www.chinasatcom.com/cn/News_Info.aspx?m=20101221173706030603&n=20110321091418060015|title=中星5D|archivedate=7 April 2011|access-date=26 July 2017|publisher=China Satellite Communications|language=Chinese}}</ref> It was acquired by [[China Satellite Communications]] from subsidiary [[APT Satellite Holdings]].
===ChinaSat 5E=== ChinaSat 5E was launched in 1994, formerly known as Apstar 1.<ref name=Apstar1/> It was placed in [[geosynchronous orbit]] at a longitude of 142° East<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hkexnews.hk/listedco/listconews/SEHK/2008/0418/LTN20080418102.pdf|title=2007 Annual Report|date=18 April 2008|access-date=26 July 2017|publisher=APT Satellite Holdings}}</ref> and moved to 163° East circa 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chinasatcom.com/cn/News_Info.aspx?m=20101221173706030603&n=20130219093912543388|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130801105133/http://www.chinasatcom.com/cn/News_Info.aspx?m=20101221173706030603&n=20130219093912543388|title=中星5E|archivedate=1 August 2013|access-date=26 July 2017|publisher=China Satellite Communications|language=Chinese}}</ref> It was acquired by [[China Satellite Communications]] from subsidiary [[APT Satellite Holdings]].
===ChinaSat 6=== ChinaSat 6 were two satellites launched in 1994 and 1997. The first satellite was lost and the second suffered from reduced life.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://space.skyrocket.de/doc_sdat/dfh-3.htm|title=DFH-3 1, 2 (ZX 6 / ChinaSat 6)|date=2 June 2017|access-date=26 July 2017|publisher=skyrocket.de}}</ref>
=== ChinaSat 6A === ChinaSat 6A was launched in 2010. Formerly known as SinoSat 6.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chinasatcom.com/n782704/c791167/content.html|title=中星6A|date=2 December 2014|access-date=25 July 2017|publisher=China Satellite Communications|language=Chinese}}</ref>
=== ChinaSat 6B === The ChinaSat 6B satellite was manufactured by [[Thales Alenia Space]], based on the [[List_of_Spacebus_satellites#Spacebus_4000C2|Spacebus 4000C2]] platform. It has 38 transponders, and is being used for TV transmissions and shortwave jamming across China, Southeast Asia, the Pacific and Oceania. It has a planned useful life of 15 years.<ref> {{cite news | url = http://www.hindu.com/thehindu/holnus/008200707052021.htm | title = China launches French-made communications satellite | publisher = The Hindu | location=Chennai, India | date=5 July 2007}}</ref> The launch, on a [[Long March 3B]] rocket, was successfully conducted on 5 July 2007. The broadcast used for some shortwave [[radio jamming]] purposes in China is carried on one of the Chinasat 6B transponders.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.satdirectory.com/firedrake.html |title=Firedrake - The source of China's Radio Jammer found on Chinasat 6B |publisher=Satdirectory the free-to-air satellite directory}}</ref>
United States [[International Traffic in Arms Regulations|ITAR]] restrictions prohibited the export of satellite components for satellites launched on Chinese rockets. In response, Thales Alenia built ChinaSat 6B as an ITAR-free satellite, containing no restricted U.S. satellite components.<ref> {{cite news | url = https://www.usatoday.com/tech/science/space/2007-07-06-china-launches-satellite_N.htm | title = China launches satellite despite restrictions | publisher = USA TODAY | date=2007-07-06 | accessdate=2010-04-28 | first=Peter B. | last=de Selding}}</ref> However, the US Department of State did not accept the ITAR-free status of these satellites and fined the US company Aeroflex $8 million for exporting satellite components. In 2013, Thales Alenia discontinued its ITAR-free satellite line.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Ferster|first1=Warren|title=U.S. Satellite Component Maker Fined $8 Million for ITAR Violations|url=http://spacenews.com/37071us-satellite-component-maker-fined-8-million-for-itar-violations/|work=SpaceNews|date=5 September 2013}}</ref>
=== ChinaSat 8 === {{main|ProtoStar#ProtoStar I}}
ChinaSat 8 was built by [[Space Systems/Loral]] and scheduled for launch in April 1999 on a [[Long March 3B]] rocket.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Associate Administrator for Commercial Space Transportation, Federal Aviation Administration|title=Commercial Space Transportation Quarterly Launch Report|date=|url=https://www.faa.gov/about/office_org/headquarters_offices/ast/media/quarter9902.pdf}}</ref> However, the U.S Department of State blocked its export to China under [[International Traffic in Arms Regulations|ITAR]] regulations.<ref name="zenio2006">{{cite news|last1=Zelnio|first1=Ryan|title=A short history of export control policy|url=http://www.thespacereview.com/article/528/1|work=The Space Review|date=January 9, 2006}}</ref> The satellite was sold to ProtoStar in 2006.<ref>{{cite press release|author=Loral|title=Loral to convert unlaunched ChinaSat-8 for ProtoStar|url=https://spaceflightnow.com/news/n0701/07protostar1/|publisher=Spaceflight Now|date=January 7, 2007}}</ref>
=== ChinaSat 9 === {{main|ChinaSat 9}} On 9 June 2008 the [[China Great Wall Industrial Corporation]] used a Long March 3B lifting off from [[Xichang Satellite Launch Center|Xichang]] pad LA-2 to launch Chinasat 9.<ref>{{cite web |date=2008-06-09 |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2008-06/09/content_8334551.htm |title=China launches French-built satellite |publisher=Xinhua News Agency}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mister-info.com/?cmd=displaystory&story_id=10817 |title=Long March 3B rocket launches Chinasat-9 satellite |publisher=Mister-Info.com}}</ref>
=== ChinaSat 9A === {{main|ChinaSat 9A}} ChinaSat 9A was based on the [[DFH-4]] bus. It was launched in June 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chinasatcom.com/n782704/c1694711/content.html|title=中星9A|date=21 July 2017|access-date=25 July 2017|publisher=China Satellite Communications|language=Chinese}}</ref>
=== ChinaSat 10 === {{main|ChinaSat 10}} ChinaSat 10 was based on the DFH-4 bus. It was launched in 2011. Formerly known as SinoSat 5.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chinasatcom.com/n782704/c791222/content.html|title=中星10号|date=2 December 2014|access-date=25 July 2017|publisher=China Satellite Communications|language=Chinese}}</ref>
=== ChinaSat 11 === ChinaSat 11 was based on the [[DFH-4]] bus. It was launched in May 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chinasatcom.com/n782704/c791241/content.html|title=中星11号|date=2 December 2014|access-date=25 July 2017|publisher=China Satellite Communications|language=Chinese}}</ref>
===ChinaSat 12=== {{main|ChinaSat 12}} ChinaSat 12 was launched in 2012. Formerly known as Apstar 7B. A backup of [[Apstar 7]], Apstar 7B was acquired by [[China Satellite Communications]] from its subsidiary [[APT Satellite Holdings]] in 2010.<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.hkexnews.hk/listedco/listconews/sehk/2012/0925/LTN20120925452_C.pdf|title=關連交易|date=25 September 2012|access-date=25 July 2017|publisher=APT Satellite Holdings|language=Chinese}}</ref> It was based on Thales Alenia Space Spacebus-4000C2.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.apstar.com/en/apstar-fleet/apstar-7b/|title=APSTAR-7B Characteristics|access-date=26 July 2017|publisher=APT Satellite}}</ref>
===ChinaSat 15=== {{main|Belintersat-1}} ChinaSat 15, aka Belintersat-1, was based on the DFH-4 bus. It was launched on 16 January 2016 00:57 (Beijing time).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chinasatcom.com/n782704/c1162009/content.html|title=中星15号|date=17 February 2017|access-date=25 July 2017|publisher=China Satellite Communications|language=Chinese}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://cn.cgwic.com/belintersat/news.html|title=中国成功发射白俄罗斯通信卫星一号|date=20 January 2016|access-date=25 July 2017|publisher=China Great Wall Industry Corporation|language=Chinese}}</ref> ===ChinaSat 16=== {{section-stub|date=July 2017}}
== References == {{Reflist}}

{{use dmy dates|date=September 2016}} {{use American English|date=September 2016}}
{{infobox organization | name = Climate-Alliance Germany | native_name = Klima-Allianz Deutschland | native_name_lang = German | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | logo = | logo_size = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | abbreviation = | formation = {{start date and age|df=yes|paren=yes|2007|04|24}} | type = [[Advocacy group]] | status = | purpose = | headquarters = | location = Schwedenstraße 15a, D–13357 Berlin, Germany | language = | key_people = | mission = | website = {{URL|www.klima-allianz.de/english/}} | remarks = | footnotes = }}
'''Climate-Alliance Germany''' ({{lang-de|Klima-Allianz Deutschland}}) is a network of 110 civil society organizations, including environment groups, development groups, trade unions, and consumer associations.<ref>http://www.climate-alliance-germany.de/about-us/members/</ref><ref name="clew-2016"> {{cite news | title = Climate-Alliance Germany | date = 2016 | website = Clean Energy Wire (CLEW) | location = Berlin, Germany | url = https://www.cleanenergywire.org/experts/climate-alliance-germany | access-date = 2016-09-09 }} </ref> Founded in 2007, the aim of the Alliance is to provide a common front to apply pressure to German decision-makers to adopt climate protection measures.<ref name="wwf-2007"> {{cite web | title = "Klima-Allianz" gegründet: Kirchen, Umweltverbände und Entwicklungsorganisationen rufen Bundesregierung zum Handeln auf | trans-title = "Climate-Alliance" founded: churches, environmental groups, and development organizations call on government to act | language = German | date = 24 April 2007 | website = WWF Germany | location = Berlin, Germany | url = http://www.wwf.de/die-klima-allianz/ | access-date = 2016-09-09 }} </ref> Prominent members include [[World Wide Fund for Nature|WWF]], [[Bund für Umwelt und Naturschutz Deutschland|BUND]] (or Friends of the Earth Germany), and [[IG Bauen-Agrar-Umwelt|IG BAU]] (a multi-sector trade union).
A key issue for the Alliance is the prevention of new coal-fired power plants (the Anti-Coal Campaign).<ref name="dirty-thirty-2014"> {{cite book | title = Europe's dirty 30: how the EU's coal-fired power plants are undermining its climate efforts | date = July 2014 | publisher = CAN Europe, WWF European Policy Office, HEAL, the EEB, and Climate Alliance Germany | location = Brussels, Belgium | url = http://www.wwf.de/fileadmin/fm-wwf/Publikationen-PDF/Studie-Dirty-Thirty-2014.pdf | access-date = 2016-09-09 }} </ref> The Alliance wants the German government to phase-out coal (''Kohleausstieg'') and promote renewable energy.
== Activities ==
=== Alternative Energy Summit ===
The Alliance organizes an Alternative Energy Summit annually to discuss energy and climate policy issues.
In a April 2016 media report over the future of [[RWE]], an Alliance expert stated that the power company had become completely unprofitable after failing to adapt to the [[Energiewende in Germany|German Energiewende]].<ref name="muenten-etal-2016"> {{cite news | first1 = Thomas | last1 = Münten | first2 = Heiko | last2 = Rahms | first3 = Andreas | last3 = Seibert | title = RWE in der Krise | trans-title = RWE in crisis | language = German | date = 12 April 2016 | publisher = [[ZDF]] frontal21 | location = Mainz, Germany | url = http://www.zdf.de/frontal-21/energiekonzern-rwe-in-der-krise-kommunen-in-nordrhein-westfalen-tragen-altlasten-43061390.html | access-date = 2016-09-14 }} </ref>
=== Berlin Climate Talks ===
Since November 2015, the Alliance has organized the Berlin Climate Talks. The format is now four per year, each with a different theme. The launch event was devoted to civil society proposals for a more climate-friendly aviation concept for Germany.
=== Anti-Coal Campaign ===
Started in 2008, the most important campaign for the Alliance is the Anti-Coal Campaign. The campaign coordinates and supports civil society activities to prevent new coal power plants from being built in Germany. Coal is more carbon intensive than other fossil fuels, so that even the most advanced lignite-fired power plant discharges twice as much {{co2}} as a gas-fired power plant. Coal power plants have a lifetime of 40–50 years and create high {{co2}} emissions throughout their lives. Without a coal phase-out, the Alliance questions whether the German government can meet its future {{co2}} emissions targets.
Following a [[Greenpeace]] protest against [[lignite]] mining in the [[Lusatia|Lausitz]] in September 2013, a petition of 112,157 signatures in support was handed to the Lausitz authorities. Daniela Setton, an energy policy speaker from the Alliance, commented that it was the most successful collection of signatures against a new German opencast mine ever.<ref name="deutschlandradio-2013"> {{cite news | title = Gegner legten Braunkohlezufuhr lahm | trans-title = Protesters paralyzed lignite supply | language = German | date = 17 September 2013 | publisher = Deutschlandradio | location = Germany | url = http://www.deutschlandradio.de/gegner-legten-braunkohlezufuhr-lahm.331.de.html?dram:article_id=261999 | access-date = 2016-09-14 }} </ref>
In July 2014 the Alliance co-authored and co-published a report on the top 30 most polluting coal-fired power plants in Europe and called for their decommissioning.<ref name="gutmann-etal-2014"> {{cite book | first1 = Kathrin | last1 = Gutmann | first2 = Julia | last2 = Huscher | first3 = Darek | last3 = Urbaniak | first4 = Adam | last4 = White | first5 = Christian | last5 = Schaible | first6 = Mona | last6 = Bricke | title = Europe's dirty 30: how the EU's coal-fired power plants are undermining its climate efforts | date = July 2014 | publisher = CAN Europe, WWF European Policy Office, HEAL, the EEB, and Climate-Alliance Germany | location = Brussels, Belgium | url = http://awsassets.panda.org/downloads/dirty_30_report_finale.pdf | access-date = 2016-09-22 }} </ref>
In July 2016, the Alliance, together with [[Bund für Umwelt und Naturschutz Deutschland|BUND]], the [[Heinrich Böll Foundation]], and the [[Rosa Luxemburg Stiftung|Rosa Luxemburg Foundation]] released a report on the aftermath of [[lignite]] mining in Germany.<ref name="iass-2016"> {{cite web | title = Braunkohle-Tagebau: Studie mahnt, Gelder für Renaturierung und Bewältigung der Langzeitschäden zu sichern | trans-title = Lignite opencast mining: study urges funds be secured for restoration and for addressing the long-term damage | language = German | date = 7 July 2016 | publisher = IASS Potsdam (Institute for Advanced Sustainability Studies) | location = Potsdam, Germany | url = http://www.iass-potsdam.de/de/news-media/news/braunkohle-tagebau-studie-mahnt-gelder-fuer-renaturierung-und-bewaeltigung-der | access-date = 2016-09-14 }}</ref><ref name="holdinghausen-2016"> {{cite news | first = Heike | last = Holdinghausen | title = Der Atomausstieg als Vorbild | trans-title = The nuclear phase out as a role model | language = German | date = 8 July 2016 | newspaper = [[Die Tageszeitung]] (taz) | location = Berlin, Germany | url = http://www.taz.de/!5307528/ | access-date = 2016-09-14 }}</ref><ref name="wronski-etal-2016"><!-- alternative url: http://www.foes.de/pdf/2016-06-FOES-IASS-Finanzielle-Vorsorge-Braunkohle.pdf --> {{cite book|url=http://www.die-klima-allianz.de/wp-content/uploads/2016-06_FOES_IASS-Finanzielle-Vorsorge-im-Braunkohlebereich.pdf|title=Finanzielle Vorsorge im Braunkohlebereich: Optionen zur Sicherung der Braunkohlerückstellungen und zur Umsetzung des Verursacherprinzips|last2=Fiedler|first2=Swantje|last3=Schäuble|first3=Dominik|date=June 2016|publisher=Forum Ökologisch-Soziale Marktwirtschaft (FÖS) and IASS Potsdam (Institute for Advanced Sustainability Studies)|location=Berlin and Potsdam, Germany|trans-title=Financial provisions in the area of lignite: options for securing the lignite reserves and the implementation of the polluter pays principle|access-date=2016-09-14|first1=Rupert|last1=Wronski}} </ref> The report, co-authored by [[:de:Institute for Advanced Sustainability Studies|IASS Potsdam]], argues that the financial resources needed to remedy the damage caused by lignite mining are not adequately backed up by the existing mining operators [[Vattenfall]] (who later sold its lignite-fired plants and mines to [[Energetický a průmyslový holding|EPH]]), [[RWE]], and [[:de:MIBRAG|MIBRAG]].
=== Global Climate Day of Action ===
For the annual Global Climate Day of Action, the Alliance organizes nationwide demonstrations for the general public, to protest at the lack of environmental awareness in politics and the economy and to encourage climate protection measures.
Alliance spokesperson Katharina Reuter, in an interview with [[Deutschlandfunk]] in December 2011, criticized the exit by [[Canada]] from the [[Kyoto Protocol]].<ref name="geers-2011"> {{cite news | first = Theo | last = Geers | title = Der Ausstieg ist "auf jeden Fall alarmierend" — Gespräch | trans-title = The exit is "definitely alarming" — Interview with Katharina Reuter | date = 13 December 2011 | publisher = Deutschlandfunk | location = Germany | url = http://www.deutschlandfunk.de/der-ausstieg-ist-auf-jeden-fall-alarmierend.697.de.html?dram:article_id=78763 | access-date = 2016-09-14 }} </ref>
=== Networking and training ===
In addition to activist activities, the Alliance mediates and maintains the substantive and tactical networks of its member organizations and with other civil society actors. In addition, the Alliance offers its members opportunities for further development, for example through specific seminars.
== See also == {{Portal|Germany|Energy}} * [[Climate Action Network]] – an umbrella group for environmental NGOs active on climate change * {{section link|List of environmental organizations|Germany}} * [[The Climate Reality Project]] – a non-profit organization involved in climate change education and advocacy * [[VENRO]] (Association of German Development and Humanitarian Aid NGOs)

'''Color index''' is a [[geology|geological term]], an indicator of the types of [[minerals]] present, and the specific type of [[Rock (geology)|rock]]. The color index of an [[igneous rock]] is a measure of the ratio of dark colored, or [[mafic]], minerals to light colored, or [[felsic]], minerals.<ref name="thisoldearth.net">Igneous Rock Color Index: [http://www.thisoldearth.net/Igneous-Rocks_color.cfm Igneous Rock Color Index], accessdate: March 21, 2017</ref>
Speaking broadly, mineral colour points out the [[specific gravity]] of the mineral, as minerals that are lighter in color tend to weigh less. Darker minerals typically tend to contain more of relatively heavy [[Chemical element|element]]s, notably [[iron]], [[magnesium]], and [[calcium]].<ref name="britannica.com">Britannica.com: [https://www.britannica.com/science/color-index-igneous-rock colour index | igneous rock | Britannica.com], accessdate: March 21, 2017</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
