revision.text:
[[File:Wallingford, Connecticut tornado damage picture.jpg|thumb|250px|Picture of a house destroyed by the [[Wallingford Tornado of 1878]]]] Although historically the [[United States|U.S.]] [[U.S. state|state]] of [[Connecticut]] is not typically known to fall casualty to [[tornado]]es, more than 100 of these powerful storms have affected the state in modern history, resulting in at least 48 deaths, 780 injuries, and more than $500 million in damage.<ref name="NCDC">{{cite web|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~storms |title=NCDC Storm Events |accessdate=2008-05-13 |year=2008 |publisher=[[National Climatic Data Center]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080503053157/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~storms |archivedate=May 3, 2008 }}</ref><ref>[https://archive.is/20120731080214/http://www.courant.com/news/weather/hc-weacol0503.artmay03,0,1068269.story Tornado Safety Rules Worth Reviewing] [[Hartford Courant]] Online. Accessed 2008-05-13.</ref> This list of tornadoes in the state is likely incomplete, as official records date back only to 1950 for tornadoes in the United States.<ref name="NCDC"/>
As with most of the [[northeastern United States]], the number of tornadoes peaks in the summer months, normally in July or August. [[Hartford County, Connecticut|Hartford County]] has had the most tornadoes in the state, although since 1950 [[Litchfield County, Connecticut|Litchfield County]] has reported the most tornadoes. Several areas have been struck more than once, and [[Waterbury, Connecticut|Waterbury]] has been struck by no less than four tornadoes since 1955.
From 1953 to 1991, Connecticut recorded an average of about 1.3 tornadoes per year, ranked 43rd in the United States.<ref>Grazulis, p. 18</ref> Although Connecticut tornadoes are typically weak, isolated events can be violent. Three tornadoes of [[Fujita scale|F4 intensity]] have affected the state in its history, as well as at least 27 tornadoes of F2 intensity or greater. Outbreaks of three or more tornadoes in a single day occurred in 1786, 1787, 1878, 1973, 1989, 1998, 2001 and 2018. The year 1973 was particularly active; eight tornadoes occurred on six separate days. The year 2018 has the highest number of tornadoes recorded in the state in a year, with nine total. The [[1878 Wallingford tornado]] killed at least 29 and likely 34 people in [[Wallingford, Connecticut|Wallingford]], the most by any tornado event in [[History of Connecticut|Connecticut history]].
==Before 1831== *June 14, 1648: A "great tempest" downed trees somewhere in present-day [[Hartford County, Connecticut|Hartford County]].<ref name="Ludlam list">Ludlam, pg. 201</ref> *June 20, 1682: A violent storm, including one or more likely tornadoes, devastated forests in southern Connecticut, affecting areas north of [[Fairfield, Connecticut|Fairfield]] across the [[Housatonic River]] before passing out into [[Long Island Sound]] between [[Milford, Connecticut|Milford]] and [[New Haven, Connecticut|New Haven]]. The damage was worst around present-day [[Shelton, Connecticut|Shelton]], where a path was cut a half-mile wide where there was "scarce a tree left standing".<ref>Grazulis, p. 552</ref><ref>Ludlam, pp. 4–5</ref> *1728 or 1729: A possible tornado passed through [[New Britain, Connecticut|New Britain]] and/or [[Wethersfield, Connecticut|Wethersfield]].<ref name="Ludlam list"/><ref name="NYT08131878">{{cite news | title = The hurricanes of the past | work = [[The New York Times]] | page = 2 | date = 1878-08-13 }}</ref> *August 17, 1784: Two tornadoes struck central Connecticut. The first tornado touched down near present-day [[Roxbury, Connecticut|Roxbury]], then known as "Shipague-Neck". It travelled through the village of [[South Britain, Connecticut|South Britain]], injuring five people, with one man injured so that "his life was in great danger". Ten houses, five barns, and three mills were badly damaged or destroyed.<ref>{{cite news | title = Untitled article | url = http://proquest.umi.com/pqdweb?index=1&did=835585652&SrchMode=2&sid=6&Fmt=10&VInst=PROD&VType=PQD&RQT=309&VName=HNP&TS=1235205772&clientId=61720| publisher = Hartford Courant| page = 3| date = 1784-08-31|accessdate=2009-02-21 }}</ref> The second tornado injured one person while moving down a hillside west of [[Southington, Connecticut|Southington]].<ref name="Grazulis 553">Grazulis, p. 553</ref> *August 23, 1786: As many as six tornadoes did a great deal of damage in [[Windham County, Connecticut|Windham County]]. Twenty homes and sixty-three barns were destroyed, as well as {{convert|1000|acre|km2}} of dense forest. One woman was killed and five people were injured in [[Woodstock, Connecticut|Woodstock]]. Leaves from destroyed trees rained down heavily in [[Providence, Rhode Island]].<ref name="Grazulis 553"/><ref>Ludlam, pp. 11–12</ref><!--Another source: [https://books.google.com/books?id=1w-CLumC_3IC&pg=PA214&lpg=PA214&dq=Connecticut+tornado&source=web&ots=XFe1JKzjRE&sig=Nyj2bEhOQMm5iePhMII6sNp0tdQ#PPA121,M1 Historic Storms of New England, Page 121]--> *August 15, 1787: The [[Four-State Tornado Swarm]] of 1787 was the largest tornado outbreak recorded to date, and affected most of [[New England]]. The first in the state touched down around 1:30 PM near New Britain, traveling along nearly the same path as a tornado in 1728 or 1729. This tornado was nearly as violent as the [[Wallingford Tornado of 1878]]. A mother and two of her children were killed in [[Wethersfield, Connecticut|Wethersfield]], and 10 others were injured before the tornado lifted outside of the town.<ref name="tornado project">[[Tornado Project]]. [http://www.tornadoproject.com/alltorns/worstts.htm#CT "Worst" Tornadoes] {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/6fh9gLEFL?url=http://www.tornadoproject.com/alltorns/worstts.htm |date=2016-03-02 }} Retrieved on 2007-07-02.</ref> What may have been another tornado caused additional damage as far east as [[Coventry, Connecticut|Coventry]]. Another tornado struck [[East Windsor, Connecticut|East Windsor]], damaging several homes and barns. Yet another touched down near [[Killingly, Connecticut|Killingly]], moving northeast into [[Rhode Island]] and [[Massachusetts]].<ref name="NYT08131878"/><ref name="Grazulis 553"/> *June 19, 1794: A tornado destroyed several structures in Milford injuring four people, while a separate tornado cut through [[Branford, Connecticut|Branford]]. A strange incident was recorded where a tree was uprooted and carried, fully upright, along a road in [[New Milford, Connecticut|New Milford]], along with several other large objects. A barn door was found {{convert|10|mi|km}} from its source. Some loss of life likely occurred from one or both tornadoes.<ref name="Grazulis 553"/><ref>Cerveny, p. 317</ref> *October 8, 1797: A tornado touched down in [[North Salem, New York]], moving into [[Fairfield County, Connecticut|Fairfield County]]. Six people were injured in [[Ridgefield, Connecticut|Ridgefield]], and possible tornado damage continued as far as Long Island Sound in Branford.<ref name="Grazulis 553"/> *August 2, 1799: A tornado destroyed two houses in [[New London County, Connecticut|New London County]], affecting the towns of [[Franklin, Connecticut|Franklin]], [[Lebanon, Connecticut|Lebanon]], and [[Bozrah, Connecticut|Bozrah]].<ref name="Grazulis 554">Grazulis, p. 554</ref> *June 30, 1808: One or more tornadoes moved from [[Windsor, Connecticut|Windsor]] to Coventry, killing one person.<ref name="Grazulis 554"/> *July 22, 1808: Trees and buildings were damaged by a tornado which moved from East Windsor to [[Bolton, Connecticut|North Bolton]].<ref name="Grazulis 554"/> *July 16, 1810: A tornado produced damage in or around [[Somers, Connecticut|Somers]].<ref name="Grazulis 554"/> *August 1, 1812: A tornado passed from [[Westchester County, New York]] into [[Greenwich, Connecticut|Greenwich]].<ref name="Grazulis 555">Grazulis, p. 555</ref> *July 22, 1817: Tornado produced tree damage from [[Woodbury, Connecticut|Woodbury]] to [[Watertown, Connecticut|Watertown]].<ref name="Grazulis 555"/> *August 13, 1817: A tornado destroyed 23 buildings in [[Wallingford, Connecticut|Wallingford]].<ref name="Grazulis 555"/> *August 14, 1820: A tornado touched down east of [[Norwalk, Connecticut|Norwalk]].<ref>Grazulis, p. 556</ref> *June 3, 1836: A long-lived tornado tracked 30 miles (48 km) from [[Dutchess County, New York]] to [[Salisbury, Connecticut|Salisbury]], seriously injuring many people.<ref name="Grazulis 559">Grazulis, p. 559</ref> *July 31, 1839: Six homes were damaged or destroyed on the west side of New Haven.<ref name="Grazulis 559"/> A "heavy rumbling noise" was heard throughout the city.<ref>Cerveny, p. 43</ref> *August 7, 1839: A possible tornado passed through a then-uninhabited area of Wallingford.<ref name="NYT08131878"/> *August 14, 1840: A possible tornado struck [[Woodbridge, Connecticut|Woodbridge]].<ref name="Ludlam203">Ludlam, pg. 203</ref>
==1850–1949== *August 9, 1851: A "tornado" (possibly a [[squall line]]) affected [[New Hartford, Connecticut|New Hartford]], [[Suffield, Connecticut|Suffield]] and [[Windsor, Connecticut|Windsor]].<ref name="Ludlam203"/> *July, 1865: A tornado may have struck [[Birmingham, Connecticut|Birmingham]].<ref>Ludlam, pg. 204</ref> *August 17, 1872: What may have been a small tornado hit [[Windsor Locks, Connecticut|Windsor Locks]].<ref>Grazulis, p. 577</ref> *September 15, 1876: A {{convert|300|yd|m|adj=on}} wide tornado unroofed several homes in northern [[Bridgeport, Connecticut|Bridgeport]].<ref>{{cite news | title = A Connecticut hurricane | work = [[The New York Times]]| page = 5| date = 1876-08-16 }}</ref> *August 18, 1877: "Something like a tornado", described as a "whirling mass of black clouds" cut across [[Hartford, Connecticut|Hartford]], tearing down trees and branches.<ref>{{cite news | title = Furious storm in Connecticut | work = [[The New York Times]]| page = 7| date = 1877-08-19 }}</ref>
*August 9, 1878: At least three tornadoes affected the state from a single storm system. The first touched down in [[South Kent]], causing major damage but no injuries. The second, the [[Wallingford Tornado of 1878]], touched down just outside Wallingford. A severe tornado, likely an F4, it smashed through the north side of town, completely destroying dozens of houses. At least 29 people were killed in that town (likely 34), the most by any tornado event in Connecticut history. A third tornado moved through [[Durham, Connecticut|Durham]] and Killingsworth, unroofing houses but again causing no injuries.<ref>Grazulis, p. 596</ref><ref name="Wallingford report"> {{cite book|title=Annual Report of the Chief Signal-Officer|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oL0tAAAAIAAJ&pg=RA1-PA654&lpg=RA1-PA654&dq=Wallingford+tornado+of+1878&source=web&ots=vkwrjr5NbM&sig=k7TweLaX6_jqna_GOLgRghilXLs&hl=en#PRA2-PA656,M1|format=PDF |accessdate=2008-05-14|year=1878|publisher=Government Printing Office|location=Washington, D.C.|pages=654–661}}</ref>
*May 29, 1880: A tornado touched down in [[Suffield, Connecticut|Suffield]], moving northeast and crossing the [[Connecticut River]]. It destroyed 25 buildings in [[Thompsonville, Connecticut|Thompsonville]] and [[Enfield, Connecticut|Enfield]].<ref>Grazulis, p. 610</ref> *July 14, 1881: A "terrific storm" downed trees "in all directions" in [[Meriden, Connecticut|Meriden]], also damaging a school and several other buildings.<ref>{{cite news | title = Terrific storm in Connecticut | work = [[The New York Times]]| page = 5| date = 1881-07-15}}</ref> *September 14, 1882: A tornado touched down outside of [[Winsted, Connecticut|Winsted]], destroying nine homes and five barns as it moved into town. Twenty people were injured, two of whom may have later died.<ref>Grazulis, p. 617</ref> *August 25, 1885: A tornado passed through the towns of [[Bloomfield, Connecticut|Bloomfield]] and Windsor, crossing the Connecticut River before dissipating. Nearly the entire tobacco crop in the area was destroyed, at a loss in the millions of dollars. Another tornado may have struck [[East Hartford, Connecticut|East Hartford]] a few weeks earlier.<ref>{{cite news | title = Great damage elsewhere | work = [[The New York Times]]| page = 1 | date = 1885-08-26 }}</ref> *September 12, 1886: A tornado touched down outside of [[Ellington, Connecticut]], destroying barns and downing trees before lifting near [[Burnside, Connecticut]].<ref>Grazulis, p. 641</ref> *September 27, 1899: A tornado passed from Norwalk to near Ridgefield, causing damage to trees and roofs in a path 50 to 300 feet (15 to 91 m) wide. Some buildings were completely destroyed.<ref>{{cite news | title = Tornado in Connecticut | work = [[The New York Times]]| page = 1| date = 1899-09-28 }}</ref> *September 15, 1901: A damaging tornado swept through the village of [[Shelton, Connecticut|Huntington]] around 7 PM. One man was killed when his house was torn from its foundation. Several barns were destroyed—one "completely disappeared"—and hundreds of trees were leveled on a path from modern-day Shelton to [[Monroe, Connecticut|Monroe]].<ref>{{cite news | title = Tornado in Connecticut | work = [[The New York Times]]| page = 7| date = 1901-09-17 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title = Great Electrical Storm | publisher = [[Bridgeport Evening Farmer]] | page = 1 | date = 1901-09-16 }}</ref> *August 28, 1911: A tornado cut a {{convert|3|mi|km|adj=on|sigfig=1}} path through New Milford, Litchfield County, uprooting trees and damaging roofs.<ref>{{cite news | title = Tornado hits Connecticut | work = [[The New York Times]]| page = 2| date = 1911-08-29 }}</ref> *June 12, 1918: A "baby tornado" (possibly a [[microburst]]) caused $50,000 in damage, mainly to roofs and windows, in New Britain, Hartford County.<ref>{{cite news | title = Baby Tornado Causes $50,000 Damage in New Britain Visit | url = http://proquest.umi.com/pqdweb?index=126&did=784012632&SrchMode=1&sid=1&Fmt=10&VInst=PROD&VType=PQD&RQT=309&VName=HNP&TS=1210805431&clientId=61720| publisher = Hartford Courant| page = 1| date = 1918-06-13|accessdate=2008-10-13 }}</ref> *August 7, 1918: A possible tornado touched down in [[Westbrook, Connecticut|Westbrook]], causing roof damage and downing trees. A house was moved off its foundation in [[Fenwick, Connecticut|Fenwick]].<ref>{{cite news | title = Tornado Wrecks House at Fenwick | url = http://proquest.umi.com/pqdweb?index=121&did=765542192&SrchMode=1&sid=1&Fmt=10&VInst=PROD&VType=PQD&RQT=309&VName=HNP&TS=1210805431&clientId=61720| publisher = Hartford Courant| page = 3| date = 1918-08-10|accessdate=2008-10-13 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title = Cyclone Rages along the Shore | url = http://proquest.umi.com/pqdweb?index=16&did=765858842&SrchMode=1&sid=2&Fmt=10&VInst=PROD&VType=PQD&RQT=309&VName=HNP&TS=1210805838&clientId=61720| publisher = Hartford Courant| page = 9| date = 1918-08-09|accessdate=2008-10-13 }}</ref> *September 18, 1918: A tornado cut a path 130 to 160 feet (40 to 50 m) wide from [[Groton, Connecticut|Groton]], through [[Mystic, Connecticut|Mystic]], and out into Long Island Sound. Small buildings, roofs, trees and telephone poles were damaged heavily. Several people received minor injuries from flying debris.<ref>{{cite news | title = Cyclone Damages M. F. Plant's Estate | url = http://proquest.umi.com/pqdweb?index=101&did=737986712&SrchMode=1&sid=3&Fmt=10&VInst=PROD&VType=PQD&RQT=309&VName=HNP&TS=1210808934&clientId=61720| publisher = Hartford Courant| page = 1| date = 1918-09-19|accessdate=2008-10-13 }}</ref> *August 30, 1920: A storm with "tornado features" caused damage on a small line from eastern [[Hamden, Connecticut|Hamden]] to [[Guilford, Connecticut|Guilford]]. A fireworks factory was destroyed, roofs were removed from four warehouses and a house, and hundreds of trees and utility poles were toppled. One boy was killed and thirty-three others were injured.<ref>{{cite news | title = One Dead, Many Hurt In North Haven Whirlwind | publisher = Hartford Courant| page = 1| date = 1920-09-01 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title = Tuesday's Storm | publisher = Hartford Courant| page = 10| date = 1920-09-02 }}</ref> *July 13, 1922: A weak tornado tracked across Hartford, downing tree branches and utility poles.<ref>{{cite news | title = Hats, Trees, Wires Suffer in Storm |url = http://proquest.umi.com/pqdweb?index=21&did=749146762&SrchMode=1&sid=3&Fmt=10&VInst=PROD&VType=PQD&RQT=309&VName=HNP&TS=1210807583&clientId=61720| publisher = Hartford Courant| page = 1| date = 1922-07-14|accessdate=2008-10-13 }}</ref> *July 26, 1937: A tornado produced F2 damage while passing just south of [[Terryville, Connecticut|Terryville]] and just north of [[Bristol, Connecticut|Bristol]].<ref>Grazulis, p. 873</ref> *September 24, 1942: A tornado destroyed a church in [[Plainville, Connecticut|Plainville]] and a garage in Bristol along a {{convert|3|mi|km|adj=on|sigfig=1}} path.<ref>Grazulis, p. 904</ref>
==1950–1974== [[Image:1950–1999 Connecticut tornado tracks.png|thumb|400px|Tornado tracks from 1950 to 1999 in Connecticut, with their ratings on the Fujita scale]] *July 12, 1950: An F2 tracked 10 miles (16 km) through Middlesex County.<ref name="NCDC"/><ref name="severe plot"/> *July 14, 1950: An F2 touched down in Ridgefield around 7:30 AM, tearing the roof off the high school and downing trees through the center of town. Three people were injured.<ref name="NCDC"/><ref>{{cite news | title = Tornado in Ridgefield | publisher = [[New York Times]] | page = 19 | date = 1950-07-14 }}</ref> *August 20, 1951: An F2 briefly touched down in [[Willington, Connecticut|Willington]], Tolland County.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~16334|title= Event Record Details, 20 Aug 1951, 1530 CST|accessdate= 2008-05-13|year= 2008|publisher= [[National Climatic Data Center]]|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110520010956/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~16334|archivedate= 2011-05-20|df= }}</ref> *August 21, 1951: A long-tracked F2 touched down in southwestern Litchfield County, passing more than 40 miles (64 km) well into Hartford County. Another tornado, an F3 (some sources say F2), touched down in northern Middlesex County, unroofing a factory and causing $100,000 in damage. Nine people were injured in the first tornado, with another eight injured in the second.<ref name="severe plot"/><ref>Grazulis, p. 960</ref> *May 10, 1954: An F3 (some sources say F2) hit Windsorville at 9:30 AM, destroying a house and some sheds, injuring two and causing $30,000 in damage. Additionally, an F2 touched down in northwestern Hartford County that afternoon.<ref name="severe plot"/><ref>Grazulis, p. 980</ref> *October 24, 1955: An F1 touched down in central Hartford County, while an F2 touched down near Waterbury.<ref name="severe plot"/> *August 8, 1956: An F0 briefly touched down in [[Glastonbury, Connecticut|East Glastonbury]], Hartford County.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~16344|title= Event Record Details, 08 Aug 1956, 1530 CST|accessdate= 2008-05-13|year= 2008|publisher= [[National Climatic Data Center]]|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110520011001/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~16344|archivedate= 2011-05-20|df= }}</ref> *June 19, 1957: An F1 touched down in central [[Glastonbury, Connecticut|Glastonbury]], Hartford County.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~16350|title= Event Record Details, 19 Jun 1957, 1400 CST|accessdate= 2008-05-13|year= 2008|publisher= [[National Climatic Data Center]]|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110520011040/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~16350|archivedate= 2011-05-20|df= }}</ref> *August 15, 1958: An F1 briefly touched down in northern Fairfield.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~16354|title= Event Record Details, 15 Aug 1958, 1150 CST|accessdate= 2008-05-13|year= 2008|publisher= [[National Climatic Data Center]]|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110520011052/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~16354|archivedate= 2011-05-20|df= }}</ref> *August 21, 1958: An F1 briefly touched down in [[Colebrook, Connecticut|Colebrook]], Litchfield County.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~16356|title= Event Record Details, 21 Aug 1958, 1915 CST|accessdate= 2008-05-13|year= 2008|publisher= [[National Climatic Data Center]]|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110520011108/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~16356|archivedate= 2011-05-20|df= }}</ref> *September 7, 1958: An F2 injured two in Willington, Tolland County.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~16357|title= Event Record Details, 07 Sep 1958, 1510 CST|accessdate= 2008-05-13|year= 2008|publisher= [[National Climatic Data Center]]|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110520011129/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~16357|archivedate= 2011-05-20|df= }}</ref> *May 12, 1959: An F2 touched down in Salisbury, damaging mostly trees along a one-mile (1.6 km) path.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~16358|title= Event Record Details, 12 May 1959, 1545 CST|accessdate= 2008-10-11|year= 2008|publisher= [[National Climatic Data Center]]|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110520025403/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~16358|archivedate= 20 May 2011|df= }}</ref> *May 30, 1959: An F1 briefly touched down in Bloomfield, damaging a few greenhouses.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~16359|title= Event Record Details, 30 May 1959, 1430 CST|accessdate= 2008-10-11|year= 2008|publisher= [[National Climatic Data Center]]|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110520025424/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~16359|archivedate= 20 May 2011|df= }}</ref> *August 29, 1959: An F0 briefly touched down in southeastern New Haven County.<ref name="severe plot"/> *April 26, 1961: An F1 briefly touched down in western Tolland County.<ref name="severe plot"/> *May 24, 1962: An F3 tracked through northern New Haven and southern Hartford Counties. The tornado produced "near-F4 damage" in parts of Waterbury and Southington, with more than 200 buildings destroyed and another 600 damaged. One person was killed, with another fifty injured, and the tornado caused $4,000,000 in damage along its {{convert|11|mi|km|adj=on}} path.<ref name="severe plot"/><ref>Grazulis, p. 1042</ref> *June 18, 1962: An F2 briefly touched down in eastern Litchfield County.<ref name="severe plot"/> *August 19, 1965: An F2 tracked 6 miles (10 km) through northern Tolland County.<ref name="severe plot"/> *August 11, 1966: An F2 touched down in northern Litchfield County, passing east-northeast into Massachusetts.<ref name="severe plot"/> *August 9, 1968: An F1 briefly touched down near Danbury.<ref name="severe plot"/> *August 17, 1968: An F1 touched down in southern Tolland County.<ref name="severe plot"/> *August 20, 1968: An F1 briefly touched down in northern Litchfield County.<ref name="severe plot"/> *October 3, 1970: An F1 injured one in northern Hartford County.<ref name="severe plot"/> *July 19, 1971: An F2 touched down near Norwalk.<ref name="severe plot"/> *July 29, 1971: An F3 (some sources say F2) moved along Main Street in downtown Waterbury, unroofing a factory and damaging some houses. Two people were injured.<ref name="severe plot"/><ref>Grazulis, p. 1127</ref> *August 7, 1972: An F1 tracked almost 10 miles (16 km) across northern Litchfield County.<ref name="severe plot"/> *August 9, 1972: An F1 touched down in southern Litchfield County.<ref name="severe plot"/> *July 12, 1973: An F2 touched down in southeastern Litchfield County.<ref name="severe plot"/> *June 28, 1973: An F1 injured one person in western Hartford County.<ref name="severe plot"/> *June 29, 1973: An F1 touched down in northwestern Litchfield County.<ref name="severe plot"/> *August 31, 1973: An F2 briefly touched down in central Hartford County.<ref name="severe plot"/> *September 6, 1973: An F2 touched down in eastern Hartford County, damaging houses in [[Manchester, Connecticut|Manchester]], [[Vernon, Connecticut|Vernon]], and [[Talcott, Connecticut|Talcottville]].<ref name="severe plot"/><ref>Grazulis, p. 1144</ref> *September 18, 1973: Three tornadoes briefly touched down, an F1 in Greenwich, an F2 in southwestern Hartford county, and another F1 in southern Tolland County.<ref name="severe plot"/> *July 3, 1974: An F1 tracked {{convert|5|mi|km|sigfig=1}} southeast through southern Litchfield County.<ref name="severe plot"/>
==1975–1999== [[File:May 29 1995 Connecticut supercell velocity.gif|thumb|250px|[[NEXRAD]] radar loop of the [[supercell]], with a visible [[hook echo]], which produced the May 29, 1995 tornado in [[Southbury, Connecticut|Southbury]]]] *June 19, 1975: An F1 tracked 5 miles (8 km) through central Litchfield County.<ref name="severe plot"/> *July 20, 1975: An F1 touched down near New Milford.<ref name="severe plot"/> *June 30, 1976: An F2 touched down in northern Litchfield County.<ref name="severe plot"/> *October 3, 1979: The [[Windsor Locks, Connecticut Tornado]], an extremely destructive F4 tornado, one of the worst in Connecticut history, killed three and injured 500 in northern Hartford County. The tornado struck without warning, tearing through [[Bradley International Airport]], destroying more than a dozen airplanes, and narrowly missing a [[Boeing 727]] which was attempting to land. About 100 homes were completely leveled. Most of the $200+ million in damage was done in Windsor Locks and Suffield. This was the sixth-most damaging tornado in US history.<ref>Grazulis, p. 1216</ref> *July 28, 1982: An F1 tracked through central New Haven County.<ref name="severe plot"/> *August 1, 1983: An F0 struck Middlesex County.<ref name="severe plot"/> *July 5, 1984: An F2 tracked from Bristol to [[Farmington, Connecticut|Farmington]], injuring one person and causing $500,000 in damage to houses and cars.<ref name="severe plot"/><ref>Grazulis, p. 1261</ref> *June 24, 1985: An F1 tracked 10 miles (16 km) across central Windham County.<ref name="severe plot"/> *August 26, 1985: An F1 touched down in extreme eastern Windham County, passing into Rhode Island.<ref name="severe plot"/> *July 10, 1989: The [[Northeastern United States tornado outbreak of 1989]] produced at least three tornadoes in Litchfield and New Haven Counties, causing more than $100 million in damage. The first tornado, possibly a family of three tornadoes, destroyed [[Cathedral Pines]] Forest, and caused F2 damage to trees and homes in [[Cornwall, Connecticut|Cornwall]], [[Milton, Connecticut|Milton]], and [[Bantam, Connecticut|Bantam]], injuring four people.<ref>Grazulis, p. 1289</ref> The second tornado, also an F2, unroofed or severely damaged 50 homes and injured 70 people on a path through Watertown, [[Oakville, Connecticut|Oakville]], and northern Waterbury. The final tornado was one of the worst in Connecticut history, cutting a {{convert|5|mi|km|adj=on|sigfig=1}} path through [[Hamden, Connecticut|Hamden]]. The F4 destroyed almost 400 structures and injured 40 people. No one was killed by these devastating tornadoes, though a girl was killed when [[Downburst|straight-line winds]] blew a tree onto her tent. *June 29, 1990: An F0 briefly touched down in [[Danbury, Connecticut|Danbury]]. Seven people were injured by flying glass.<ref name="tornado project"/> *July 5, 1992: An F0 struck near [[New Fairfield, Connecticut|New Fairfield]].<ref name="severe plot">Data from the [[Storm Prediction Center]] archives, which are accessible through [http://www.spc.noaa.gov/software/svrplot2/ SeverePlot], free software created and maintained by [[John Hart (meteorologist)|John Hart]], lead forecaster for the SPC.</ref> *July 14, 1992: An F1 briefly touched down in southern Windham County.<ref name="severe plot"/> *August 4, 1992: An F0 struck central Hartford County, and an F1 struck the Long Hill section of [[Trumbull, Connecticut|Trumbull]].<ref name="severe plot"/><ref>{{cite news | first = Sheridan | last = Chris | title = Tornado touches down in Trumbull | publisher = Hartford Courant | page = D.1 | date = 1992-08-05 }}</ref> *July 10, 1993: An F0 briefly touched down in western Windham County.<ref name="severe plot"/> *June 29, 1994: A strong microburst accompanied by an F0 struck [[Avon, Connecticut|Avon]]. Many trees were downed, but there was very little property damage.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~194063|title= Event Record Details, 29 Jun 1994, 1416 EST|accessdate= 2008-05-13|year= 2008|work= NCDC Storm Events database|publisher= [[National Climatic Data Center]]|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110519231839/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~194063|archivedate= 2011-05-19|df= }}</ref> *May 29, 1995: An F1 tracked 2 miles (3 km) from [[South Britain, Connecticut|South Britain]] to [[Southbury, Connecticut|Southbury]] around 6:20 PM. Many trees were downed, and several homes sustained minor damage.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~194158|title= Event Record Details, 29 May 1995, 1823 EST|accessdate= 2008-05-13|year= 2008|work= NCDC Storm Events database|publisher= [[National Climatic Data Center]]|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110519231856/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~194158|archivedate= 19 May 2011|df= }}</ref> *July 23, 1995: An F0 struck the town of [[Prospect, Connecticut|Prospect]]. A tractor-trailer was thrown {{convert|200|yd}} through the air, but no injuries were reported.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~194164|title= Event Record Details, 23 Jul 1995, 1830 EST|accessdate= 2008-05-13|year= 2008|work= NCDC Storm Events database|publisher= [[National Climatic Data Center]]|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110519231920/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~194164|archivedate= 2011-05-19|df= }}</ref> *July 3, 1996: An F1 touched down just north of downtown Waterbury, causing damage to [[Wilby High School]].<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~252538|title= Event Record Details, 03 Jul 1996, 05:40:00 AM EST|accessdate= 2008-05-13|year= 2008|work= NCDC Storm Events database|publisher= [[National Climatic Data Center]]|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110519232014/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~252538|archivedate= 2011-05-19|df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | first = Barbara | last = Stewart | title = Connecticut Hit By a Tornado, Hail and Floods | url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C06E6DB1039F936A35754C0A960958260 |publisher = [[New York Times]] | page = D.1 | date = 1996-07-05 }}</ref> *July 9, 1996: An F1 downed trees in Monroe.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~252547|title= Event Record Details, 09 Jul 1996, 06:00:00 PM EST|accessdate= 2008-05-13|year= 2008|work= NCDC Storm Events database|publisher= [[National Climatic Data Center]]|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110519232054/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~252547|archivedate= 2011-05-19|df= }}</ref> *May 31, 1998: An F1, part of a [[Late-May 1998 Tornado Outbreak and Derecho#May 31 New York event|large tornado outbreak]], briefly touched down near [[Washington, Connecticut|Washington]].<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~313753|title= Event Record Details, 31 May 1998, 08:30:00 PM EST|accessdate= 2008-05-13|year= 2008|work= NCDC Storm Events database|publisher= [[National Climatic Data Center]]|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110519232108/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~313753|archivedate= 19 May 2011|df= }}</ref> *June 30, 1998: Two F1 tornadoes briefly touched down in [[Killingworth, Connecticut|Killingworth]] and [[Lyme, Connecticut|Lyme]], and an F0 briefly touched down in [[Chester, Connecticut|Chester]].<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~313794|title= Event Record Details, 30 Jun 1998, 07:30:00 PM EST|accessdate= 2008-05-13|year= 2008|work= NCDC Storm Events database|publisher= [[National Climatic Data Center]]|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110519232114/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~313794|archivedate= 2011-05-19|df= }}</ref> {{clear}}
==2000–present== [[File:Shelton, CT 2009-07-31 tornado damage 1.jpg|thumb|250px|Damage to a [[power pole]] in [[Shelton, Connecticut|Shelton]] from the July 31, 2009 tornado]] *August 16, 2000: An F1 touched down in Ellington. It tossed several large trailers through the air and damaged a cow barn.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~382976|title= Event Record Details, 16 Aug 2000, 12:35:00 PM EST|accessdate= 2008-05-13|year= 2008|work= NCDC Storm Events database|publisher= [[National Climatic Data Center]]|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110519232123/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~382976|archivedate= 2011-05-19|df= }}</ref> *June 23, 2001: An isolated supercell produced three tornadoes in the state. The first, an F1, hit a golf course in Washington, demolishing a storage building and a tennis court, and injuring one person. The second tornado, rated an F2, touched down in [[Torrington, Connecticut|Torrington]] near Torrington Middle School, damaging the roof and destroying bleachers and a storage shed. The final tornado, an F0, produced minor damage to the [[Hartland, Connecticut|East Hartland]] fire station.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~417482|title= Event Record Details, 23 Jun 2001, 01:00:00 PM EST|accessdate= 2008-05-13|year= 2008|work= NCDC Storm Events database|publisher= [[National Climatic Data Center]]|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110519232149/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~417482|archivedate= 2011-05-19|df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~417483|title= Event Record Details, 23 Jun 2001, 01:50:00 PM EST|accessdate= 2008-05-13|year= 2008|work= NCDC Storm Events database|publisher= [[National Climatic Data Center]]|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110520010920/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~417483|archivedate= 2011-05-20|df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~417483|title= Event Record Details, 23 Jun 2001, 02:18:00 PM EST|accessdate= 2008-05-13|year= 2008|work= NCDC Storm Events database|publisher= [[National Climatic Data Center]]|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110520010920/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~417483|archivedate= 2011-05-20|df= }}</ref> *July 1, 2001: An F0 tracked {{convert|10|mi|km}} across southern Litchfield County, touching down seven times along its path from New Milford to [[Roxbury, Connecticut|Roxbury]].<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~417489|title= Event Record Details, 01 Jul 2001, 03:25:00 PM EST|accessdate= 2008-05-13|year= 2008|work= NCDC Storm Events database|publisher= [[National Climatic Data Center]]|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110519232159/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~417489|archivedate= 2011-05-19|df= }}</ref> *May 31, 2002: An F1 touched down in [[Brookfield, Connecticut|Brookfield]], followed by a brief, F0 touchdown in Southbury along [[Interstate 84 (east)|Interstate 84]].<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~451859|title= Event Record Details, 31 May 2002, 06:40:00 PM EST|accessdate= 2008-05-13|year= 2008|work= NCDC Storm Events database|publisher= [[National Climatic Data Center]]|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110519232226/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~451859|archivedate= 19 May 2011|df= }}</ref> *June 6, 2002: An F1 destroyed two acres (8,000 m<sup>2</sup>) of "healthy mature forest" in Salisbury.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~451866|title= Event Record Details, 05 Jun 2002, 10:55:00 PM EST|accessdate= 2008-05-13|year= 2008|work= NCDC Storm Events database|publisher= [[National Climatic Data Center]]|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110519232233/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~451866|archivedate= 2011-05-19|df= }}</ref> *June 16, 2002: An F0 briefly touched down in [[Lanesville, Connecticut|Lanesville]]. In [[Montville, Connecticut|Montville]], a [[waterspout]] formed over Gardner Lake, causing F1 damage to trees, houses, and cars upon crossing onto land.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~451873|title= Event Record Details, 16 Jun 2002, 02:10:00 PM EST|accessdate= 2008-05-13|year= 2008|work= NCDC Storm Events database|publisher= [[National Climatic Data Center]]|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110519232248/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~451873|archivedate= 2011-05-19|df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~451884|title= Event Record Details, 16 Jun 2002, 04:30:00 PM EST|accessdate= 2008-05-13|year= 2008|work= NCDC Storm Events database|publisher= [[National Climatic Data Center]]|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110519232309/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~451884|archivedate= 2011-05-19|df= }}</ref> *July 12, 2006: The [[2006 Westchester County tornado|Westchester tornado]] that produced F2 damage across the border in New York entered Greenwich at 4:01 PM, producing F1 damage on the north side of town. It may have briefly touched down a second time just north of the [[Merritt Parkway]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.erh.noaa.gov/okx/pns/torjul06.txt|title=Public Information Statement|accessdate=2007-06-02|author=[[National Weather Service]], [[Upton, New York]]|date=2006-07-14|format=Text file}}</ref> *May 16, 2007: Just three months after the switch to the [[Enhanced Fujita Scale]] for rating tornadoes, a [[skipping tornado]], rated EF1, tracked 4 to 5 miles (6 to 8 km) from [[Bethel, Connecticut|Bethel]] to Newtown. Widespread wind damage also affected other parts of the state.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.erh.noaa.gov/okx/pns/tormay07.txt|title=Public Information Statement|accessdate=2007-06-02|author=[[National Weather Service]], [[Upton, New York]]|date=2007-05-18|format=Text file|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110611150133/http://www.erh.noaa.gov/okx/pns/tormay07.txt|archivedate=2011-06-11|df=}}</ref> *May 28, 2007: An EF0 [[landspout]] damaged the roof of a barn in Somers, on an otherwise calm day.<ref>{{cite news |author=Associated Press |title=Small twister hits Somers |url=http://www.connpost.com/fastsearchresults/ci_6012235 |publisher=[[Connecticut Post]] |page=A7 |date=2007-05-28 |accessdate=2007-06-01 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928004022/http://www.connpost.com/fastsearchresults/ci_6012235 |archivedate=2007-09-28 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | author = Storm Prediction Center | title = 20070528's Storm Reports | url = http://www.spc.noaa.gov/climo/reports/070528_rpts.html | date = 2007-06-01 | accessdate = 2007-06-02 }}</ref> http://www.spc.noaa.gov/climo/reports/180515_rpts.html
*June 26, 2009: An EF1 tornado hit the town of [[Wethersfield, Connecticut|Wethersfield]]. Widespread damage across town especially near the area of Wolcott Hill. Many downed trees caused damages, most notably in Old Wethersfield where a tree split a house in town, and destroyed a front porch.<ref>[https://archive.is/20120722210646/http://www.courant.com/news/local/hc-storm-slams-state-0627,0,6820532.story Weather Service Confirms It: Tornado Hit Wethersfield Friday]</ref> Damage was estimated at around $2.4 million.<ref>[http://www.boston.com/news/weather/articles/2009/08/01/officials_tornado_touched_down_in_conn/ Officials: Tornado touched down in Conn.]</ref> *July 31, 2009: Significant wind damage was reported across the state, including two EF1 tornadoes. The first tornado caused tree and minor property damage along a {{convert|0.5|mi|km|adj=on}} path through eastern [[Shelton, Connecticut|Shelton]].<ref>[http://www.nbcconnecticut.com/news/local-beat/Tornado-Hits-Shelton.html Tornado Hits Shelton]</ref><ref>[http://www.erh.noaa.gov/okx/readtext.php?file=pns/07312009_sheltontor.txt Public Information Statement...Corrected] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110611212816/http://www.erh.noaa.gov/okx/readtext.php?file=pns%2F07312009_sheltontor.txt |date=2011-06-11 }}</ref> The second downed trees along a sporadic {{convert|2.75|mi|km|sigfig=2|adj=on}} path in [[Madison, Connecticut|Madison]].<ref>{{Cite web |author = Goodman/GC/MAS |title = Public Information Statement |url = http://forecast.weather.gov/product.php?site=NWS&issuedby=OKX&product=PNS |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fforecast.weather.gov%2Fproduct.php%3Fsite%3DNWS%26issuedby%3DOKX%26product%3DPNS&date=2009-08-07 |archivedate = 2009-08-07 |publisher = National Weather Service |location = [[Upton, New York]] |date = 2009-08-06 |accessdate = 2009-08-06 |deadurl = yes |df = }}</ref> Many trees were also snapped and uprooted in [[Fairfield, Connecticut|Fairfield]], [[Milford, Connecticut|Milford]], [[Guilford, Connecticut|Guilford]], [[Chester, Connecticut|Chester]], [[Old Lyme, Connecticut|Old Lyme]] and [[Naugatuck, Connecticut|Naugatuck]].<ref>[http://www.spc.noaa.gov/climo/reports/090731_rpts.html 20090731's Storm Report]</ref><ref>[http://www.erh.noaa.gov/okx/readtext.php?file=pns/07312009_naugmicro.txt Public Information Statement] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110611213334/http://www.erh.noaa.gov/okx/readtext.php?file=pns%2F07312009_naugmicro.txt |date=2011-06-11 }}</ref> *June 24, 2010: A tornado briefly touched down in downtown Bridgeport, embedded within a larger area of strong wind damage which downed trees and damaged several buildings. 9 roofs were damaged causing the city to declare a state of emergency.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://forecast.weather.gov/product.php?site=NWS&issuedby=OKX&product=PNS |title=Public Information Statement |first=Pollina |last=Joe |date=June 25, 2010 |publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration |work=National Weather Service in Upton, New York |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5qkp0mmbR?url=http://forecast.weather.gov/product.php?site=NWS&issuedby=OKX&product=PNS&format=CI&version=1&glossary=0 |archivedate=June 25, 2010 |accessdate=2010-06-25 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The National Weather service confirmed it as an EF1 tornado, estimating it to be 100 yards wide with winds of at least 100 mph. The damage was especially concentrated to the east end of Bridgeport and the Lordship section of Stratford. Both areas were declared states of emergencies for at least 24 hours after the storm hit.<ref>{{Cite journal|journal=[[Connecticut Post]]|title=Tornado confirmed in Bridgeport|date=June 25, 2010|url=http://www.ctpost.com/news/article/Tornado-confirmed-in-Bridgeport-536870.php|accessdate=2012-09-08}}</ref> *July 21, 2010: Several severe storms spawned five brief tornadoes and spread straight-line wind damage across the state. One touchdown was reported in Litchfield, and an EF1 tornado was confirmed in Bristol. The Bristol tornado was on the ground for {{convert|1.5|mi|km|}} and had winds at 90 mph. A touchdown was also confirmed in Litchfield, Thomaston, the Terryville section of Plymouth and Bristol Wednesday afternoon, the National Weather Service said. The tornado touched down in East Litchfield around Litchfield Road, in Thomaston near D. Welter Way, in Terryville near North Street and in Bristol near Blakeslee and High streets. Tree tops were twisted off and several trees were uprooted. In Bristol, the tornado's path was {{convert|1.5|mi|km|}} long and about {{convert|25|yd|m|}} wide. Wind gusts were about {{convert|90|mph|km/h|}}. The paths in the other three towns were shorter. All of the touchdowns were caused by the same supercell.<ref name="NCDC"/> *June 9, 2011: A brief EF1 tornado occurred within a larger area of straight-line winds in Litchfield County.<ref>{{cite web|work=National Climatic Data Center|publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|year=2011|accessdate=July 15, 2013|title=Connecticut Event Report: EF1 Tornado|url=http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/stormevents/eventdetails.jsp?id=325082}}</ref> *July 1, 2013: A series of three tornadoes touch down across the state; one in Fairfield County and two in Hartford County. Majority of impact limited to downed trees, though the EF1 caused notable structural damage near [[East Windsor, Connecticut|East Windsor]].<ref name="NWSUptonJuly1–2">{{cite web|work=National Weather Service Office in Upton, New York|publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|date=July 2, 2013|accessdate=July 2, 2013|title=Tornado Confirmed In The Towns Of Greenwich And Stamford In Fairfield County Connecticut|url=http://www.nws.noaa.gov/view/validProds.php?prod=PNS&node=KOKX}}</ref><ref name="NWSTauntonJuly1-1">{{cite web|work=National Weather Service Office in Taunton, Massachusetts|publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|date=July 1, 2013|accessdate=July 11, 2013|title=Tornado Confirmed Near Windsor in Hartford County Connecticut|url=http://mesonet.agron.iastate.edu/wx/afos/p.php?pil=PNSBOX&e=201307020000}}</ref> *July 10, 2013: An EF1 tornado caused tree damage along an {{convert|11.2|mi|km|adj=on}} long intermittent path in Tolland County.<ref>{{cite web |work=National Weather Service Office in Boston, Massachusetts |publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration |date=July 12, 2013 |accessdate=July 15, 2013 |title=Tornado Confirmed Near Andover...Coventry and Mansfield in Tolland County CT |url=http://www.nws.noaa.gov/view/validProds.php?prod=PNS |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6I86UeHgP?url=http://www.nws.noaa.gov/view/validProds.php?prod=PNS&node=KBOX |archivedate=July 15, 2013 |df= }}</ref> *July 27, 2014: An EF0 tornado caused minor damage in [[Wolcott, Connecticut|Wolcott]], mostly at and near the high school.<ref>{{cite web|work=National Weather Service Office in Upton, New York|publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|date=July 27, 2014|accessdate=July 27, 2014|title=Tornado confirmed near Wolcott in New Haven County Connecticut|url=https://nwschat.weather.gov/p.php?pid=201407272036-KOKX-NOUS41-PNSOKX}}</ref> *August 10, 2016: An EF0 tornado caused minor damage in the Montowese section of North Haven.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.weather.gov/okx/storm08102016 |title=August 10th EF-0 Tornado Confirmed near North Haven in New Haven County, Connecticut and Mattituck in Suffolk County, New York |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=2016-08-10 |publisher=National Weather Service |access-date=2018-05-17}}</ref> *May 15, 2018: Four tornadoes, three EF1 and one unrated, snapped and uprooted numerous trees in Litchfield and New Haven County. The first touched down in Winsted, causing damage to houses and trees across 8 city blocks. The second was observed over [[Saville Dam|Barkhamsted Reservoir]], which caused no damage and so was not rated on the EF scale.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.weather.gov/aly/May15Severe |title=Severe Thunderstorms May 15, 2018 |author=<!--Not stated--> |publisher=National Weather Service |access-date=2018-05-17}}</ref> The third tornado struck Southbury and [[Oxford, Connecticut|Oxford]], damaging the roof of a school. The final tornado passed through [[Beacon Falls, Connecticut|Beacon Falls]], [[Bethany, Connecticut|Bethany]], and northern Hamden near [[Sleeping Giant (Connecticut)|Sleeping Giant State Park]]. A barn was destroyed in Bethany.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.weather.gov/okx/StormSurveys |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180517124339/https://www.weather.gov/okx/StormSurveys |dead-url=no|title=NWS Storm Surveys May 16, 2018 |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=2018-05-16 |archive-date=2018-05-17 |publisher=National Weather Service |access-date=2018-05-17}}</ref> Many roads were left impassible due to downed trees, and several people were trapped in cars.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nbcconnecticut.com/news/local/Two-EF-1-Tornadoes-Hit-Connecticut-Tuesday-National-Weather-Service-482869331.html |title=Two EF-1 Tornadoes Hit Connecticut Tuesday: National Weather Service |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=2018-05-16 |website=[[WVIT]] |access-date=2018-05-17}}</ref> This was part of a larger severe weather outbreak in the Northeastern United States that produced at least 7 tornadoes, and also produced widespread severe straight line winds that killed 5 people.<ref>{{cite web | author = Storm Prediction Center | title = 20180515's Storm Reports | url = http://www.spc.noaa.gov/climo/reports/180515_rpts.html | date = 2018-05-17 | accessdate = 2018-05-17 }}</ref>
* July 17, 2018: An EF-0 tornado touched down briefly west of Ashford Lake, in Ashford, with peak winds of 80 to 85 miles per hour, and caused minor damage.<ref>https://www.nbcconnecticut.com/news/local/National-Weather-Service-to-Investigate-Storm-Damage-in-Windham-County--488489901.html</ref>
*August 4, 2018: An EF-0 tornado with winds of approximately 80 miles per hour touched down in Woodstock, causing minor property damage and moderate tree damage. The thunderstorm that sparked the Woodstock tornado then moved into Webster, MA, where another tornado, this one much more destructive, touched down. {{fact|date=August 2018}}
*October 2, 2018: Two tornadoes occurred in the state that day. An EF-1 tornado struck [[New Canaan, Connecticut]] with winds exceeding 100 miles an hour. The path was approximately 300 feet wide and began at about 5:29 PM, after a [[Tornado Watch]] was issued.<ref>https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/us/tornado-confirmed-in-new-canaan-survey-team-studying-norwalk-damage/ar-BBNTTcm</ref> An EF-0 tornado touched down in [[Mansfield, Connecticut]] after the EF-1, with winds up to 70 mph being recorded. The path was about a half mile wide and caused very little damage. The only [[Tornado Warning]] issued by the National Weather Service for this storm occurred in New Canaan, after the tornado there touched down.<ref>http://www.courant.com/breaking-news/hc-br-mansfield-tornado-20181004-story.html</ref> *October 29, 2018: An EF-0 tornado in [[Stonington, Connecticut|Stonington]] downed and uprooted some trees.<ref name="October29">{{cite report|url=https://mesonet.agron.iastate.edu/wx/afos/p.php?dir=next&pil=PNSOKX&e=201810301000|title=NWS DAMAGE SURVEY FOR 10/29/2018 TORNADO EVENT|date=October 30, 2018|publisher=Iowa Environmental Mesonet|accessdate=November 3, 2018|agency=National Weather Service Weather Forecast Office in New York, New York}}</ref>
==See also==
*[[Enhanced Fujita Scale]] *[[Fujita scale]] *[[List of North American tornadoes and tornado outbreaks]]

==External links== *[http://www.disastercenter.com/conn/tornado.html Connecticut Tornadoes] *[http://www.tornadoproject.com/alltorns/cttorn.htm Connecticut Tornadoes at Tornado Project] *[http://www.tornadohistoryproject.com/tornado.php?yr=%25&mo=%25&day=%25&st=Connecticut&fu=%25&co=Any&l=auto&submit=Map&ddat=on&dsta=on&dfuj=on&dfat=on&dinj=on&dwid=on&dlen=on&format=basic&p=1&s=1 Map of Connecticut Tornadoes from 1950–present]

Hunz. & A.A.Cocucci *''[[Hippeastrum amaru]]'' (Vargas) Meerow *''[[Hippeastrum andreanum]]'' Baker *''[[Hippeastrum angustifolium]]'' [[Ferdinand Albin Pax|Pax]] *''[[Hippeastrum anzaldoi]]'' (Cárdenas) Van Scheepen *''[[Hippeastrum apertispathum]]'' (Traub) H.E.Moore *''[[Hippeastrum arboricola]]'' (Ravenna) Meerow *''[[Hippeastrum argentinum]]'' (Pax) Hunz. *''[[Hippeastrum aulicum]]'' (Ker Gawl.) Herb. *''[[Hippeastrum aviflorum]]'' (Ravenna) Dutilh *''[[Hippeastrum blossfeldiae]]'' (Traub & J.L.Doran) Van Scheepen *''[[Hippeastrum brasilianum]]'' (Traub & J.L.Doran) Dutilh *''[[Hippeastrum breviflorum]]'' Herb. *''[[Hippeastrum bukasovii]]'' (Vargas) Gereau & Brako *''[[Hippeastrum caiaponicum]]'' (Ravenna) Dutilh *''[[Hippeastrum calyptratum]]'' (Ker Gawl.) Herb. *''[[Hippeastrum canterai]]'' Arechav. *''[[Hippeastrum caupolicanense]]'' (Cárdenas) Van Scheepen *''[[Hippeastrum chionedyanthum]]'' (Cárdenas) Van Scheepen *''[[Hippeastrum condemaitae]]'' (Vargas & E.Pérez) Meerow *''[[Hippeastrum correiense]]'' (Bury) Worsley *''[[Hippeastrum crociflorum]]'' Rusby *''[[Hippeastrum curitibanum]]'' (Ravenna) Dutilh *''[[Hippeastrum cuzcoense]]'' (Vargas) Gereau & Brako *''[[Hippeastrum cybister]]'' (Herb.) Benth. ex Baker *''[[Hippeastrum damazianum]]'' Beauverd *''[[Hippeastrum divijulianum]]'' (Cárdenas) Meerow *''[[Hippeastrum doraniae]]'' (Traub) Meerow *''[[Hippeastrum elegans]]'' (Spreng.) H.E.Moore *''[[Hippeastrum escobaruriae]]'' (Cárdenas) Van Scheepen *''[[Hippeastrum espiritense]]'' (Traub) H.E.Moore *''[[Hippeastrum evansiae]]'' (Traub & I.S.Nelson) H.E.Moore *''[[Hippeastrum ferreyrae]]'' (Traub) Gereau & Brako *''[[Hippeastrum forgetii]]'' Worsley *''[[Hippeastrum fragrantissimum]]'' (Cárdenas) Meerow *''[[Hippeastrum fuscum]]'' Kraenzl. *''[[Hippeastrum gertianum]]'' (Ravenna) Dutilh *''[[Hippeastrum glaucescens]]'' (Mart. ex Schult. & Schult.f.) Herb. *''[[Hippeastrum goianum]]'' (Ravenna) Meerow *''[[Hippeastrum guarapuavicum]]'' (Ravenna) Van Scheepen *''[[Hippeastrum harrisonii]]'' (Lindl.) Hook.f. *''[[Hippeastrum hemographes]]'' (Ravenna) Dutilh *''[[Hippeastrum hugoi]]'' (Vargas) Gereau & Brako *''[[Hippeastrum iguazuanum]]'' (Ravenna) T.R.Dudley & M.Williams *''[[Hippeastrum incachacanum]]'' (Cárdenas) Van Scheepen *''[[Hippeastrum intiflorum]]'' (Vargas) Gereau & Brako *''[[Hippeastrum kromeri]]'' (Worsley) Meerow *''[[Hippeastrum lapacense]]'' (Cárdenas) Van Scheepen *''[[Hippeastrum leonardii]]'' (Vargas) Gereau & Brako *''[[Hippeastrum leopoldii]]'' T.Moore *''[[Hippeastrum leucobasis]]'' (Ravenna) Dutilh *''[[Hippeastrum macbridei]]'' (Vargas) Gereau & Brako *''[[Hippeastrum machupijchense]]'' (Vargas) D.R.Hunt *''[[Hippeastrum mandonii]]'' Baker *''[[Hippeastrum maracasum]]'' (Traub) H.E.Moore *''[[Hippeastrum marumbiense]]'' (Ravenna) Van Scheepen *''[[Hippeastrum miniatum]]'' (Ruiz & Pav.) Herb. *''[[Hippeastrum mollevillquense]]'' (Cárdenas) Van Scheepen *''[[Hippeastrum monanthum]]'' (Ravenna) Meerow *''[[Hippeastrum morelianum]]'' Lem. *''[[Hippeastrum nelsonii]]'' (Cárdenas) Van Scheepen *''[[Hippeastrum oconequense]]'' (Traub) H.E.Moore *''[[Hippeastrum papilio]]'' (Ravenna) Van Scheepen *''[[Hippeastrum paquichanum]]'' (Cárdenas) Dutilh *''[[Hippeastrum paradisiacum]]'' (Ravenna) Meerow *''[[Hippeastrum paranaense]]'' (Traub) Meerow *''[[Hippeastrum pardinum]]'' (Hook.f.) Dombrain *''[[Hippeastrum parodii]]'' Hunz. & A.A.Cocucci *''[[Hippeastrum petiolatum]]'' Pax *''[[Hippeastrum pilcomaicum]]'' (Ravenna) Meerow *''[[Hippeastrum psittacinum]]'' (Ker Gawl.) Herb. *''[[Hippeastrum puniceum]]'' (Lam.) Voss. Syn. H. equestre (Aiton) *''[[Hippeastrum reginae]]'' (L.) Herb. *''[[Hippeastrum reticulatum]]'' (L'Hér.) Herb. Syn H. striatifolium (Sims) *''[[Hippeastrum rubropictum]]'' (Ravenna) Meerow *''[[Hippeastrum santacatarina]]'' (Traub) Dutilh *''[[Hippeastrum scopulorum]]'' Baker *''[[Hippeastrum starkiorum]]'' (I.S.Nelson & Traub) Van Scheepen *''[[Hippeastrum striatum]]'' (Lam.) H.E.Moore *''[[Hippeastrum stylosum]]'' Herb. *''[[Hippeastrum teyucuarense]]'' (Ravenna) Van Scheepen *''[[Hippeastrum traubii]]'' (Moldenke) H.E.Moore *''[[Hippeastrum umabisanum]]'' (Cárdenas) Meerow *''[[Hippeastrum vanleestenii]]'' (Traub) H.E.Moore *''[[Hippeastrum variegatum]]'' (Vargas) Gereau & Brako *''[[Hippeastrum viridiflorum]]'' Rusby *''[[Hippeastrum vittatum]]'' (L'Hér.) Herb. *''[[Hippeastrum wilsoniae]]'' L.J.Doran & F.W.Mey. *''[[Hippeastrum yungacense]]'' (Cárdenas & I.S.Nelson) Meerow {{Div col end}} Unplaced names include ''Hippeastrum ugentii'', considered in the Kew ''World Checklist of Selected Plant Families'' as probably a ''[[Crinum]]''. ==References== {{Commonscat|position=left|Hippeastrum|
Hippeastrum}} {{reflist|30em|refs= {{Cite web |author=WCSP |year=2011 |title=Search for ''Hippeastrum'' |work=World Checklist of Selected Plant Families |publisher=The Board of Trustees of the [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew]] |url=http://apps.kew.org/wcsp/home.do |accessdate=2011-11-20 }} {{Cite journal |last=Ochoa |first=C.M. |year=2006 |title=''Hippeastrum ugentii'' (Amaryllidaceae: Hippeastreae), a new species from central Peru |journal=Phytologia |volume=88 |issue=2 |pages=176–178 |url=http://www.phytologia.org/Phytologia%20PDFs/88%282%29pdfFiles/88%282%29176-178Ochoa.pdf |accessdate=2011-11-20 }} }} [[Category:Hippeastrum|*List]] [[Category:Lists of plant species|Hippeastrum]]

page.title: List of river basins in the United States

revision.text:
[[File:US river basin map.gif|thumb|Map of major river basins]] These are the major U.S. river basins in the U.S., as designated by the U.S. Water Resources Council.<ref name="sariv">{{cite web | url=http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/temp-and-precip/us-river-basins.php | title=U.S. River Basins | publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration National Climatic Data Center | accessdate=January 5, 2013}}</ref> Each of these river basins contain a number of smaller river basins.
==Continental==
*1. [[Pacific Northwest Basin]] *2. [[California River Basin]] *3. [[Great Basin]] *4. [[Colorado River|Lower Colorado River Basin]] *5. [[Colorado River|Upper Colorado River Basin]] *6. [[Rio Grande|Rio Grande River Basin]] *7. [[Texas Gulf Coast Basin]] *8. [[Arkansas River|Arkansas-White-Red Basin]] *9. [[Mississippi River|Lower Mississippi River Basin]] *10. [[Missouri River Basin]] *11. [[Red River of the North|Souris-Red-Rainy Basin]] *12. [[Mississippi River#Upper Mississippi|Upper Mississippi Basin]] *13. [[Great Lakes Basin]] *14. [[Tennessee River|Tennessee River Basin]] *15. [[Ohio River|Ohio River Basin]] *16. [[South Atlantic-Gulf Basin]] *17. [[Mid-Atlantic Basin]] *18. [[New England Basin]]

revision.text:
{{dynamic list}} This is a list of plants that have a [[Cooking|culinary]] role as [[vegetable]]s. "Vegetable" can be used in several senses, including culinary, [[botanical]] and legal. This list includes botanical [[fruit]]s such as pumpkins, and does not include [[herb]]s, [[spice]]s, [[cereal]]s and most [[List of fruits|culinary fruits]] and [[Nut (fruit)|culinary nuts]]. [[Edible mushroom|Edible fungi]] are not included in this list. Legal vegetables are defined for regulatory, tax and other purposes. An example would include the [[tomato]], which is a botanical [[berry (botany)|berry]], but a culinary vegetable according to the [[United States]]. == Leafy and salad vegetables == {{main|List of leaf vegetables}} [[File:Img 0717 garden cress.jpg|thumb|Garden Cress]] [[File:Iceberg lettuce in SB.jpg|thumb|Iceberg lettuce field in northern [[Santa Barbara County]].]] [[File:Spinacia oleracea Spinazie bloeiend.jpg|thumb|Spinach in flower]] [[File:Claytonia perfoliata 2003-05-19.jpg|thumb|Miner's lettuce]] {{Aligned table |col1style=width:16.0em;white-space:nowrap;padding-right:1.5em; |col2style=font-style:italic; | | {{noitalic|'''[[Binomial nomenclature|Species name]]'''}} | [[Amaranth]] | Amaranthus cruentus | [[Arugula]] | Eruca sativa | [[Beet]] (greens) | Beta vulgaris vulgaris | [[Chinese cabbage|Bok choy]] (白菜) | Brassica rapa (chinensis) | [[Borage]] greens | Borago officinalis | [[Broccoli]] (leaves{{\}}stalks) | Brassica oleracea | [[Brussels sprout]]s | Brassica oleracea (gemmifera) | [[Cabbage]] | Brassica oleracea (capitata) | [[Hypochaeris radicata|Catsear]] | Hypochaeris radicata | [[Celery]] | Apium graveolens | [[Celtuce]] | Lactuca sativa (asparagina) | [[Chaya (plant)|Chaya]] | Cnidoscolus aconitifolius aconitifolius | [[Stellaria|Chickweed]] | Stellaria | [[Chicory]] | Cichorium intybus | [[Chinese mallow]] | Malva verticillata | [[Garland Chrysanthemum]] | Chrysanthemum coronarium | [[Collard greens]] | Brassica oleracea | [[Common purslane]] | Portulaca oleracea | [[Corn salad]] | Valerianella locusta | [[Garden cress|Cress]] | Lepidium sativum | [[Dandelion]] | Taraxacum officinale | [[Dill]] | Anethum graveolens | [[Endive]] | Cichorium endivia | [[Chenopodium album|Fat hen]] | Chenopodium album | [[Fiddlehead]] | Pteridium aquilinum

{{Speciesbox |image = Milicia_roadside_small.jpg |status = LR/nt |status_system = IUCN2.3 |status_ref = <ref name=IUCN/> |genus = Milicia |species = excelsa |authority = (Welw.) C.C. Berg |synonyms = *''Chlorophora exelsa''<small> Welw., Benth. and Hook. f.</small> *''Chlorophora alba''<small> A. Chev.</small> *''Chlorophora tenuifolia''<small> Engl.</small> *''Maclura excelsa''<small> (Welw.) </small> *''Milicia africana''<small> Sim.</small> *''Morus excelsa''<small> Welw.</small> |synonyms_ref = <ref name=TRADA>{{cite web |url=https://www.trada.co.uk/wood-species/iroko/|title=''Wood Species Database: Iroko - TRADA''|accessdate=2018-08-24}}</ref> }}
'''''Milicia excelsa''''' is a [[tree]] species from the genus ''[[Milicia (plant)|Milicia]]'' of the family ''[[Moraceae]]''. It is one of two species (the other being ''[[Milicia regia]]'') yielding timber commonly known as '''African teak''', '''iroko''', '''intule''', '''kambala''', '''moreira''', '''mvule''', '''odum''' and '''tule'''.
==Distribution and habitat== African teak is distributed across tropical central Africa. Its range extends from Guinea-Bissau in the west to Mozambique in the east. It is found in [[Angola]], [[Benin]], [[Burundi]], [[Cameroon]], [[Central African Republic]], the [[Republic of the Congo]], the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]], [[Equatorial Guinea]], [[Ethiopia]], [[Gabon]], [[Ghana]], [[Ivory Coast]], [[Kenya]], [[Malawi]], [[Mozambique]], [[Nigeria]], [[Rwanda]], [[São Tomé and Príncipe]], [[Sierra Leone]], [[Sudan]], [[Tanzania]], [[Togo]], [[Uganda]] and [[Zimbabwe]]. Its natural habitat is in wet savannah, rainforest, riverine and low-altitude evergreen forests. It can tolerate an annual rainfall of less than {{convert|70|cm}} or six months of drought as long as there is a stream or a ground water source nearby.<ref name=TRADA/>
In a study done on population distribution of ''Milicia excelsa'' in 2009,<ref name=":0" /> researchers found that most of the populations that were being studied were inbred. After some analysis the researchers found that the ''Milicia excelsa'' was inbreeding due to lack of proximity to other ''Milicia excelsa'' individuals. Inbreeding could contribute to why this species is moving closer to being on the “Threatened” conservation list. If the numbers of mates available are not high enough because dispersion methods are not effective over long distances, then the species will begin to suffer from [[inbreeding depression]] (inbreeding can lead to accumulation of recessive deleterious alleles in a population).
[[File:Milicia Excelsa_(Chlorophora Excelsa)_(Bangla_-_আফ্রিকান_টিকওক).jpg|thumb|Trunk of Milicia excelsa (Chlorophora Excelsa) in [[Lawachara National Park]], Bangladesh. 2016.]]
==Description== The species is a large deciduous tree growing up to {{convert|50|m}} high. The trunk is bare lower down with the first branch usually at least {{convert|20|m}} above the ground. It often has several short buttress roots at the base. The bark is pale or dark grey, thick but little fissured, and if it gets damaged it oozes milky [[latex]]. There are a few thick branches in the crown all fairly horizontal giving an umbrella shape. The smaller branches hang down in female trees and curve up in male trees. The leaves are {{convert|5|to|10|cm}} long, ovate or elliptical with a finely toothed edge, green and smooth above and slightly downy beneath. Older leaves turn yellow, and all of the leaves have a prominent rectangular mesh of veins visible on the underside. The trees are [[dioecious]]. Male trees have white [[catkin]]s that extend {{convert|15|to|20|cm}} and dangle from twigs at the axils of the leaves. Female trees have flower spikes measuring {{convert|5|to|6|cm}} long by {{convert|2|cm|1|abbr=on}} wide, green with prominent styles. The fruit are long, wrinkled and fleshy with the small seeds embedded in the pulp.<ref name=TRADA/>
There is evidence that some of the variation that is described above amongst individuals is due to the variation in the environment. In a study done in 2010, it was found that environmental change from different regions in Benin caused much of the variation in ''Milicia excelsa''. Many studies have attributed this variation in growth to the differences in climate of regions. Specifically, soil characteristics and rainfall played a major role in the morphological variation of trunk growth of ''Milicia excelsa''.
''Milicia excelsa'' is one of two tree species (the other being ''[[Milicia regia]]'') that yield timber commonly known as '''African teak'''.
==Ecology== Flowering takes place at a range of different times, but often occurs in January and February soon after the time when most of the leaves fall or shortly before the new leaves appear. The fruits take about a month to ripen and are eaten by squirrels, bats, and birds, which then disperse the seeds in their droppings.<ref name=TRADA/> Some populations, especially plantations, are attacked by a gall mite.
A study in Ghana found that this tree relies heavily on the [[straw-coloured fruit bat]] (''Eidolon helvum'') for [[seed dispersal]], over 98% of the seed falling to the ground having passed through its gut.<ref name=Taylor>Taylor, Daniel; Kankam, Bright; Wagner, Michael [http://nau.edu/CEFNS/Forestry/Research/Ghana/Seed-Dispersal/ The role of the fruit bat, ''Eidolon helvum'', in seed dispersal, survival, and germination in ''Milicia excelsa'', a threatened West African hardwood.] Northern Arizona University School of Forestry.</ref> This seed also germinated better than uneaten seed and resisted predation longer.<ref name=Taylor/>
==Evolution== In a study <ref>1. Dainou, K., E. Laurenty, G. Mahy, O. J. Hardy, Y. Brostaux, N. Tagg, and J.-L. Doucet. "Phenological Patterns in a Natural Population of a Tropical Timber Tree Species, Milicia Excelsa (Moraceae): Evidence of Isolation by Time and Its Interaction with Feeding Strategies of Dispersers." ''American Journal of Botany'' (2012): 1453-463. Print.</ref> it was seen that isolation was caused by one or more of the animals that are known for dispersal of ''Milicia excelsa'' (i.e. Bats, rodents, and birds). It is hypothesized that the ancestor slowly developed a different flowering time from its ancestor, which led to differences in selection pressure during the time of reproduction. This, over time, has resulted in the tree that we see today commonly known as Iroko. Although this is the theory that has the most evidence, it is possible for ''Milicia excelsa'' to have evolved in a different way.
==Uses== The tree yields a strong, dense and durable dark brown hardwood timber. It is resistant to termites and is used for construction, furniture, joinery, panelling, floors and boats.<ref name="The Wood Database">{{cite web |url=https://www.wood-database.com/iroko/|title=''Iroko - The Wood Database''|accessdate=2018-08-24}}</ref>
The tree can be used in the control of erosion, and for providing shade as a roadside tree in urban areas. It grows rapidly, can be [[Coppicing|coppiced]] and is ready for cutting after about fifty years. The tree is nitrogen fixing and the leaves are used for mulching.<ref name=FAO>{{cite web |url=http://www.fao.org/docrep/X5327e/x5327e1b.htm |title=''Milicia excelsa'' |author= |date= |work= Indigenous multipurpose trees of Tanzania: uses and economic benefits |publisher=Food and Agriculture Organisation: Forestry Department |accessdate=2012-07-29}}</ref>
The tree is also used in herbal medicine. The powdered bark is used for coughs, heart problems and lassitude. The latex is used as an anti-tumour agent and to clear stomach and throat obstructions. The leaves and the ashes also have medicinal uses.<ref name=FAO/>
==Importance to the environment== In a study done on the mineralization of ''Milicia excelsa'',<ref>Braissant, Olivier, Guillaume Cailleau, Michel Aragno, and Eric P. Verrecchia. "Biologically Induced Mineralization in the Tree Milicia Excelsa (Moraceae): Its Causes and Consequences to the Environment." ''Geobiology'': 59-66. Print.</ref> it was observed that in certain conditions Milicia acts as a carbon sink. These specific conditions are characterized by presence of oxalate, bacteria for oxalate oxidation and a dry season, which are common conditions in which Milicia tends to grow. This is important because the conversion of atmospheric carbon into land carbon decreases the amount of atmospheric carbon dioxide.
Because of its importance to the environment there has been research done on how to conserve Iroko. A solution that has been proposed to help ''Milicia excelsa'' move further away from being threatened is [[agroforestry]]. It was found that agroforestry helps increase habitat for plants and animals. More importantly, agroforestry promotes the growth of any plant species by taking pressure off remnant forests that usually have to repopulate threatened species on their own.<ref name=":12" /> The people that conducted this study found that it would be a good method to use to specifically fight against the slow decline of the Iroko species.<ref name=":12"/> However, most of the people that were surveyed for the study did not use this system specifically to regenerate this species, therefore even though there is hope in helping this species the measures have not been taken to do so.
When forests are felled, isolated trees are often left standing and the tree regenerates easily. Fresh seed germinates readily but it loses viability in storage.<ref name=IUCN/>
==Conservation== Because of these and many other uses of ''Milicia excelsa'' people have over harvested this species to the point of concern. The IUCN has this species on the Red List under ‘Near Threatened’ (BIZOUX, J.-P., 2009).<ref name=":0">J.-P. Bizoux, K. Dai’nou, N. Bourland, O. J. Hardy, M. Heuertz, G. Mahy, and J.-L. Doucet, 2009, Spatial genetic structure in Milicia excelsa (Moraceae) indicates extensive gene dispersal in a low-density wind-pollinated tropical tree, Molecular Ecology, 6-10</ref> A study has reported that most of the remaining Iroko trees in Benin were conserved on farms (Ouinsavi and Sokpon, 2008).<ref name=":12">Christine Ouinsavi and Nestor Sokpon, 2008, Traditional agroforestry systems as tools for conservation of genetic resources of Milicia excelsa Welw. C.C. Berg in Benin, Agroforestry Systems, 17-26</ref> Milicia excelsa is threatened by [[habitat loss]].<ref name=IUCN>{{cite web | title=''IUCN Red List of Threatened Species'' | publisher=World Conservation Monitoring Centre | url=http://www.iucnredlist.org/search/details.php/33903/all | accessdate=2007-08-22 | year=2006}}</ref>
==Mythology== In West Africa, African teak is considered to be a sacred tree. It is often protected when the surrounding bush is cleared, ritual sacrifices take place underneath it and gifts are given to it. Fertility and birth are associated with it and its timber is used to make ceremonial drums and coffins.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fao.org/docrep/t9450e/t9450e06.htm |title=3.3 The symbolic and sacred significance of particular forest resources |work=The cultural and symbolic importance of forest resources |publisher=Food and Agriculture Organisation: Forestry Department |accessdate=2012-07-29}}</ref>
